Chapter on Symbols

analyzed: atha śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām pratīka adhikaraṇam

translated: Om, not in the symbol, for he is not that.

analyzed: manaḥ brahma iti upāsīta ityādi śruti prāptam manaḥ prabhṛti pratīkānām brahmatvena upāsanam atra pratiṣidhyate

analyzed: tatra pratīkaḥ iti adhikaraṇa saptamī iti pratītiḥ syāt

analyzed: manaḥ prabhṛti

analyzed: sa viṣṇuḥ na eva tasmāt iti pūrveṇa anvayaḥ

analyzed: nanu asaṅgataḥ yam hetuḥ

analyzed: mithyā upāsā hi anathardā

analyzed: nahi sa viṣṇuḥ pratīkam

analyzed: atas tayoḥ abheda bhāvanā mithyā upāsanā

analyzed: sā ca anarthasya eva hetuḥ

analyzed: atas na kartavyā iti evam hetu hetumat bhāvaḥ

analyzed: sūtrakṛtaḥ bhipretaḥ na punar sākṣāt

analyzed: atas na asaṅgatiḥ

analyzed: ṣaṭsu dvitīyā

IV. The chapter on the view of Brahman

translated: He gives an example: Impermanent.🔽When it is said that what is false is not spoken, people understand that what is true is spoken.

analyzed: jānanti uktam tu no satyam iti ukte satyatām api
translated: But when it is said that what is spoken is not true, they also understand its falsity.

original: āptenoktamasatyaṃ netyukte satyuktaṃ satyamiti prajā jānanti /
analyzed: āptena uktam asatyam na iti ukte sati uktam satyam iti prajāḥ jānanti
translated: When it is said that what is spoken by a reliable person is not false, people understand that what is spoken is true.

original: tathā vipralambhakenoktaṃ satyaṃ no ityukte tu tasyāsatyatāmapi jānanti /
analyzed: tathā vipralambhakena uktam satyam no iti ukte tu tasya asatya tām api jānanti
translated: Similarly, when it is said that what is spoken by a deceiver is not true, they also understand its falsity.

analyzed: satya tva asatya tvayoḥ dvayoḥ eva viruddha tā
translated: The contradiction is between truth and falsity themselves.

original: tatra āptokte 'rthe 'satyatāyāmasatyāṃ satyatāyāḥ satvamanāptokte ca satyatāyāmasatyāmasatyatāyāḥ satvaṃ ca prasiddhamityarthaḥ /
analyzed: tatra āpta ukte rthe satyatāyām asatyām satyatāyāḥ satvam anāpta ukte ca satyatāyām asatyām asatyatāyāḥ satvam ca prasiddham iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that in the case of what is spoken by a reliable person, when falsity is absent, truth is present, and in the case of what is spoken by an unreliable person, when truth is absent, falsity is present - this is well-known.

analyzed: iti uktaḥ iti pramita tva upalakṣaṇam
translated: The word spoken is a reference to being known.

analyzed: prajāḥ jānanti iti anena
translated: By the phrase people understand,

original: āvipālāṅganameṣā vyāptiḥ siddhā na kevalaṃ parīkṣakāṇāmiti sūcayati / /
analyzed: āvipāla aṅganam eṣā vyāptiḥ siddhā na kevalam parīkṣakāṇām iti sūcayati
translated: he indicates that this pervasion is established not only for the investigators, but also for the common people.

original: nanu svapne 'tra ghaṭa iti dṛṣṭvā nātra ghaṭa ityapi paśyati /
analyzed: nanu svapne ghaṭaḥ iti dṛṣṭvā na atra ghaṭaḥ iti api paśyati
translated: But in a dream, having seen 'there is a pot here', one also sees 'there is no pot here'.

analyzed: tatra ghaṭaḥ tad abhāvaḥ ca dvayam api mithyā
translated: There, the pot and its absence, both are false.

analyzed: atas vyāpti bhaṅgaḥ iti atas āha na iti
translated: Therefore, there is a contradiction of the pervasion. To this, he says 'no'.

analyzed: na svapne dvayam mithyā
translated: Even in a dream, the two are not false.

analyzed: tat kim dvayam api satyam iti atas āha tatra iti
translated: Then, are both true? To this, he says 'there'.

analyzed: tatra ekam satyam eva hi
translated: There, only one is true.

original: tatra ghaṭatadabhāvayormadhye /🔽yadābhāvasyāsatyatā tadā ghaṭaḥ satya eva /
analyzed: tatra ghaṭa tad abhāvayoḥ madhye  yadā abhāvasya asatya tā tadā ghaṭaḥ satyaḥ eva
translated: There, among the pot and its absence.🔽When the absence is false, then the pot is truly existent.

original: yadā ca ghaṭasya asatyatā tadābhāvaḥ satya evetyatharḥ /
analyzed: yadā ca ghaṭasya asatyatā tadā abhāvaḥ satyaḥ eva iti atharḥ
translated: And when the pot is false, then the absence is truly existent - this is the meaning.

original: tasmānna vyāptibhaṅga iti hiśabdārthaḥ /🔽kuto na dvayamapi mithyetyata āha bhāveti // /
analyzed: tasmāt na vyāpti bhaṅgaḥ iti hi śabda arthaḥ  kutas na dvayam api mithyā iti atas āha bhāva iti
translated: Therefore, there is no contradiction of the pervasion. This is the meaning of the word 'hi'.🔽From where are both not false? To this, he says 'existence' and 'non-existence'.

analyzed: bhāva abhāvau ubhau tatra katham mithyā bhaviṣyataḥ
translated: How can both existence and non-existence be false there?

original: yo yasyābhāvo yaśca yasyābhāvasya pratiyogī tāvubhāvapyekatraikadaiva na mithyeti vyāpteḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ yasya abhāvaḥ yaḥ ca yasya abhāvasya pratiyogī tau ubhau api ekatra ekadā eva na mithyā iti vyāpteḥ
translated: The absence of something and that which is the counter-correlate of the absence of something, both of these cannot be false at the same time and in the same place. This is the pervasion.

original: svapne 'pi ghaṭatadabhāvau kathaṃ tathā bhaviṣyata iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: svapne pi ghaṭa tad abhāvau katham tathā bhaviṣyataḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: How will the pot and its absence in a dream be like that? This is the meaning.

analyzed: vyāhatam ca bhāva abhāvayoḥ ubhayoḥ asattva varṇanam iti āśayena āha bhāvasya hi iti
translated: And the description of both existence and non-existence as non-existent is contradictory, with this intention he says 'of existence' etc.

original: bhāvasya hi niṣedhe tu nābhāvasya niṣedhanam // / / //
analyzed: bhāvasya hi niṣedhe tu na abhāvasya niṣedhanam
translated: For when the negation of existence is made, the negation of non-existence is not possible.

analyzed: hi śabdaḥ hetau
translated: The word 'hi' (means) reason.

original: bhāvasya niṣedhe kṛte tu abhāvasyaiva vihitatvāt /
analyzed: bhāvasya niṣedhe kṛte tu abhāvasya eva vihita tvāt
translated: When the negation of existence is made, non-existence itself is established.

analyzed: punar na abhāvasya niṣedhanam kartum śakyate vyāghātāt
translated: Again, the negation of non-existence cannot be made, because of contradiction.

original: evamabhāvasya niṣedhe kṛte 'bhāvābhāvo bhāva eva tadvayapto veti bhāvasya vihitatvāt punarna bhāvasya niṣedhanaṃ yuktaṃ vyāhatatvāditi /
analyzed: evam abhāvasya niṣedhe kṛte bhāva abhāvaḥ bhāvaḥ eva tad vayaptaḥ vā iti bhāvasya vihita tvāt punar na bhāvasya niṣedhanam yuktam vyāhata tvāt iti
translated: In the same way, when the negation of non-existence is made, the absence of non-existence is existence itself, which is pervaded by it. Therefore, because existence is established, again the negation of existence is not proper, because of contradiction.

original: astvevaṃ vyāptistataḥ kimityata āha svavaca iti //
analyzed: astu evam vyāptiḥ tatas kim iti atas āha sva vacaḥ iti
translated: Let it be so, there is pervasion. Then what? With this in mind he says 'by one's own words' etc.

original: svavāco 'satyatā cet syāt tasmād bhedasya satyatā // / / //
analyzed: sva vācaḥ satya tā ced syāt tasmāt bhedasya satya tā
translated: If there were falsity of one's own words, then from that there would be truth of difference.

analyzed: sva śabdena prativādī ucyate
translated: By one's own word, the opponent is referred to.

analyzed: tad vāc arthasya sakala bheda mithyātvasya
translated: Of the meaning of his words, the falsity of all difference.

original: tasmāt vyāptisadbhāvāt mithyātvaṃ satyatvaṃ ca dvau viruddhadharmau /
analyzed: tasmāt vyāpti sadbhāvāt mithyātvam satya tvam ca dvau viruddha dharmau
translated: From that, because of the existence of pervasion, falsity and truth are two contradictory properties.

analyzed: bhede tayoḥ
translated: In difference between them.

analyzed: mithyātve sati satyatvam sat syāt eva ukta vyāpti balāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: if falsity is not possible, then truth must exist by the force of the established pervasion.

analyzed: prakṛtam upasaṃharati tasmāt iti
translated: He concludes the main topic with tasmāt (therefore).

analyzed: tasmāt jīva īśayoḥ bhedaḥ ukta nyāyena gamyate
translated: Therefore, the difference between the individual soul and the Lord is understood by the stated reasoning.

analyzed: bheda mithyātva asambhavāt jīva īśayoḥ pāramārthika bhedaḥ evā ukta nyāyena dyu bhū ādi sūtraiḥ gamyate
translated: By the impossibility of the falsity of difference, the ultimate difference between the individual soul and the Lord is understood by the stated reasoning through the Dyu, Bhuh, etc. sutras.

analyzed: tathā ca tad virodhāt na idam abhedam pratipādayati sūtram iti siddham
translated: And thus, because of the contradiction with that, it is established that this sutra does not teach non-difference.

analyzed: śrutayaḥ tu prāk eva samyak vyākhyātāḥ
translated: The Upanishads have been properly explained earlier.

analyzed: viruddha guṇa satya tā ca upapāditā  pratyakṣa ādīnām atattva āvedaka tvam api
translated: And the truth of contradictory qualities has been established.🔽The falsity of perception etc. has also been refuted.

analyzed: śruti mithyātvasya aniṣṭa tvam ca samarthitam iti uktaḥ eva sūtra arthaḥ
translated: And the undesirability of the falsity of the Vedas has been proved. Thus the meaning of the sutra is stated.

analyzed: iti śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām ātmopagama adhikaraṇa anyathā vyākhyāna nirākaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the refutation of the wrong explanation of the Adhikarana on the attainment of the Self in the glorious Nyaya Sudha.
VI. The Adhikarana on Symbols

analyzed: atha śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām pratīka adhikaraṇa anyathā vyākhyā nirākaraṇam
translated: Now, in the glorious Nyaya Sudha, the refutation of the wrong explanation of the Adhikarana on Symbols.

original: evaṃ prathamasūtrasyāpavyākhyāṃ pratyākhyāya dvitīyasyāpi pratyākhyāti etasmāditi //
analyzed: evam prathama sūtrasya apavyākhyām pratyākhyāya dvitīyasya api pratyākhyāti etasmāt iti
translated: Having thus refuted the wrong explanation of the first aphorism, he refutes the second also, with Therefore...

analyzed: etasmāt ātma śabdaḥ yam paramātma abhidhā bhavet
translated: Therefore, this word ātman in this aphorism would be the designation of the supreme self.

analyzed: etasmāt ukta nyāyāt ātmā iti sūtra gataḥ yam ātma śabdaḥ paramātma abhidhā paramātmanaḥ eva abhidhāyakaḥ tāvat bhavet
translated: For this reason stated, this word ātman in the aphorism would be the designation of the supreme self, it would be the very designation of the supreme self.

analyzed: tatas kim iti atas āha pratīka iti
translated: What then? To this he says pratikē (symbol).

analyzed: pratīka viṣaya tvena viṣṇu dṛṣṭiḥ na tat bhavet
translated: The vision of Viṣṇu as the object of a symbol would not be that.

original: tat tasmātpūrvasūtragatasyātmaśabdasya paramātmavācitvānna pratīka iti pratijñāvākyasya pratīkaviṣayatvena viṣṇudṛṣṭiḥ kartavyā na bhavedityevārthaḥ
analyzed: tat tasmāt pūrva sūtra gatasya ātma śabdasya paramātma vāci tvāt na pratīkaḥ iti pratijñā vākyasya pratīka viṣaya tvena viṣṇu dṛṣṭiḥ kartavyā na bhavet iti eva arthaḥ
translated: For this reason, because the word ātman in the previous aphorism denotes the supreme self, the meaning of the statement not a symbol is that the vision of Viṣṇu as the object of a symbol should not be made.

analyzed: idam uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

analyzed: na pratīke iti atra tāvat ātmā iti iti anuvartanīyam pūrva sūtrāt
translated: In not a symbol, the word ātman should be supplied from the previous aphorism.

analyzed: anyathā pratijñā vākyasya a paripūrṇa tvāt
translated: Otherwise, the statement of the thesis would be incomplete.

analyzed: pūrva sūtre ca ātma śabdaḥ viṣṇu viṣayaḥ iti samarthitam
translated: And in the previous aphorism, it has been established that the word ātman refers to Viṣṇu.

analyzed: tathā ca pratīka viṣayāyāḥ viṣṇu dṛṣṭeḥ eva ayam pratiṣedhaḥ vyākhyeyaḥ
translated: And thus this prohibition should be explained as referring only to the seeing of Vishnu in the symbols.

original: na pratīkeṣu jīvamatiṃ badhnīyāditi tu pratijñāvyākhyāne prakṛtaparityāgo 'prakṛtasvīkāraśca prasajyeyātāmiti / /
analyzed: na pratīkeṣu jīva matim badhnīyāt iti tu pratijñā vyākhyāne prakṛta parityāgau prakṛta svīkāraḥ ca prasajyeyātām iti
translated: But if it were explained as a promise not to fix one's mind on the individual soul in the symbols, it would result in abandoning the subject matter and accepting what is not the subject matter.

analyzed: manaḥ brahma ityādi śruti artha tvena yat pratīka saṃsthita tvena iti uktam
translated: What was said as the meaning of the Upanisadic text The mind is Brahman etc. is in the state of being in the symbols.

original: tadapi notsūtratritam /🔽kintu pratīka iti saptamyantaṃ padamāvartate /
analyzed: tat api na utsūtratritam  kintu pratīke iti saptamī antam padam āvartate
translated: That also is not the meaning of the three sutras.🔽But the word pratike (in the symbol) is repeated with the seventh case ending.

analyzed: tatra ādyam viṣaya saptamī antam na iti anena sambaddhayate
translated: There, the first one ending with the seventh case of the object is connected with na (not).

analyzed: dvitīyam adhikaraṇa saptamī antam śruti vyākhyānam
translated: The second one ending with the seventh case of the topic is the explanation of the Upanisadic text.

original: ubhayatrātmetīti padadvayaṃ pūvarsūtrādanuvartata ityāśayavānprasaṅgād dvitīyaṃ vyākhyāti pratīka iti //
analyzed: ubhayatra ātmā iti iti pada dvayam pūvarsūtrāt anuvartate iti āśayavān prasaṅgāt dvitīyam vyākhyāti pratīkaḥ iti
translated: With the idea that the two words atman (self) are repeated from the previous sutra, he explains the second one incidentally, saying pratike (in the symbol).

analyzed: pratīke viṣṇuḥ iti eva tasmāt kāryā hi upāsanā
translated: In the symbol, only Vishnu - thus the worship should be performed.

original: yasmātpratīkaviṣayatvena viṣṇudṛṣṭiḥ kartavyā na bhavettasmāditi śrutyartha iti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: yasmāt pratīka viṣaya tvena viṣṇu dṛṣṭiḥ kartavyā na bhavet tasmāt iti śruti arthaḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The meaning of the Upanisadic text is: Because the vision of Vishnu should not be performed as having the symbol as its object, therefore - this is the remainder.

original: hiśabdena prathamādivibhakteḥ saptamyarthavācitvaṃ śābdikānāṃ prasiddhamiti dyotayati / /
analyzed: hi śabdena prathamā ādi vibhakteḥ saptamī artha vāci tvam śābdikānām prasiddham iti dyotayati
translated: The word 'hi' indicates that the grammarians' well-known view is that the first and other case endings denote the seventh case meaning.

analyzed: itas ca na ayam pratijñā arthaḥ iti āha na ca iti
translated: And because of this, this is not the meaning of the thesis, he says 'not' and so on.

original: na ca viṣṇuḥ pratīkaṃ yat tasmān / / / // / / //
analyzed: na ca viṣṇuḥ pratīkam yat tasmān
translated: And Vishnu is not the symbol, therefore...

analyzed: yasmāt viṣṇuḥ pratīkam
translated: Because Vishnu is the symbol.

analyzed: caśabdāt jīvasya na bhavati
translated: By the word 'ca' (and), the individual soul is not (the symbol).

original: tasmātpratīkeṣvātmeti jīva ityupāsanā na prasakteti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt pratīkeṣu ātmā iti jīvaḥ iti upāsanā na prasaktā iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Therefore, the meditation on the individual soul as 'the Self in the symbols' is not relevant, is the remainder.

analyzed: ayam arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning.

analyzed: prāptau satyām hi pratiṣedhaḥ vaktavyaḥ
translated: For when there is attainment, a prohibition should be stated.

analyzed: na ca pratīkeṣu upāsakasya ātma dṛṣṭiḥ prasaktā prasañjaka abhāvāt
translated: And the view of the worshipper as the Self in the symbols is not relevant, because there is no reason for it.

original: yattu prasañjakamuktaṃ brahmaṇa ātmatvaṃ pratīkānāṃ ca brahmavikāratvaṃ tadubhayamaprāmāṇikaṃ pramāṇaviruddhaṃ ca /
analyzed: yat tu prasañjakam uktam brahmaṇaḥ ātmatvam pratīkānām ca brahma vikāra tvam tat ubhayam aprāmāṇikam pramāṇa viruddham ca
translated: But the reason stated, that Brahman is the Self and the symbols are the modifications of Brahman, both of those are unauthoritative and contrary to authoritative knowledge.

analyzed: na hi atyanta ābhāsena prasaktiḥ bhavati
translated: For relevance does not occur through utter non-existence.

analyzed: atiprasaṅgāt  tatas prasaktai abhāvāt pratiṣedhaḥ narthakaḥ iti
translated: Because of excessive relevance.🔽Therefore, because there is no relevance, the prohibition is meaningless.

original: nahi sa iti hetuvyākhyānaṃ dūṣayati naca viṣṇuḥ pratīkaṃ yattasmāditi //
analyzed: nahi saḥ iti hetu vyākhyānam dūṣayati na ca viṣṇuḥ pratīkam yat tasmāt iti
translated: He refutes the explanation of the reason 'not' by saying 'And Vishnu is not the symbol, therefore...' .

analyzed: tad śabdaḥ hi prakṛta parāmarśe vartate prakṛtaḥ ca ātmā
translated: For the word 'that' refers to what is already mentioned, and the self is what is already mentioned.

analyzed: ātma śabdaḥ ca viṣṇu vācī eva iti samarthitam
translated: And it has been established that the word 'self' denotes only Vishnu.

original: tathāca hi yasmātsa viṣṇuḥ pratīkaṃ naiva tasmādityevārthaḥ sampadyate /
analyzed: tathā ca hi yasmāt sa viṣṇuḥ pratīkam na eva tasmāt iti eva arthaḥ sampadyate
translated: And thus the meaning becomes: because that Vishnu is not the symbol, therefore.

original: nahi sa upāsakaḥ pratīkānīti vyākhyāne tu prakṛtaparityāgenāprakṛtaparāmarśaḥ prasajyata iti /
analyzed: nahi saḥ upāsakaḥ pratīkāni iti vyākhyāne tu prakṛta parityāgena aprakṛta parāmarśaḥ prasajyate iti
translated: For if it is explained that the worshipper is not the symbols, then there would be a reference to what is not already mentioned by abandoning what is already mentioned.

analyzed: iti pratīka adhikaraṇa anyathā vyākhyāna nirākaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the refutation of the alternative explanation of the section on symbols.

analyzed: atha brahma dṛṣṭi adhikaraṇa anyathā vyākhyāna nirākaraṇam
translated: VI. The section on Brahman-vision🔽Now, the refutation of the alternative explanation of the aphorism on Brahman-vision.

analyzed: idanīm brahma dṛṣṭiḥ iti sūtrasya apavyākhyām aṇakaroti na ātmā iti
translated: Now, he refutes the wrong explanation of the aphorism 'Brahma-darshanam' (Brahman-vision) with 'Na-atma' (not-self).

analyzed: na ātmā iti upāsanā
translated: The worship is not as the self.

analyzed: iti pakṣaḥ yadā brahma dṛṣṭiḥ ca atra viruddhayate
translated: When this view is contradicted by Brahman-vision here,

analyzed: na ātmā iti upāsanā iti eka deśa utkīrtanena na pratīke na hi saḥ
translated: by mentioning only a part of 'not as the self, the worship', it is said 'not in the symbols, for he is not'.

analyzed: iti samagra sūtra artham anuvadati
translated: He repeats the complete meaning of the aphorism.

analyzed: pratīkeṣu ātmā iti jīvaḥ iti upāsanā na kāryā
translated: The worship as the self, as the individual soul, should not be done in the symbols.

original: nahi sa upāsakaḥ pratīkāni iti pakṣo yadā ityevaṃ pūrvasūtravyākhyānaṃ yadā tadātra pratīkeṣu brahmadṛṣṭiśca viruddhayate /
analyzed: nahi saḥ upāsakaḥ pratīkāni iti pakṣaḥ yadā iti evam pūrva sūtra vyākhyānam yadā tadā atra pratīkeṣu brahma dṛṣṭiḥ ca viruddhayate
translated: For when the view is that the upāsaka is not the symbols, then the view of Brahman in the symbols, as explained in the previous aphorism, is contradicted.

analyzed: caśabdaḥ pavyākhyāna nirāsa samuccaye
translated: The word 'ca' (and) is for the purpose of including the refutation of the wrong explanation.

analyzed: etat vivṛṇoti saḥ iti
translated: He explains this with 'sa' (he).

analyzed: sa nā iti yuktiḥ tatra api samā iti ukta viruddha tā
translated: The reasoning 'sa na' (he is not) is also applicable there, and the contradiction of the stated (view) follows.

original: pratīkānāmātmatvenopāsanasyākartavyatve tvayā yā tādātmyābhāvalakṣaṇā sa neti yuktirabhihitā
analyzed: pratīkānām ātma tvena upāsanasya akartavya tve tvayā yā tādātmya abhāva lakṣaṇā sa nā iti yuktiḥ abhihitā
translated: When the meditation on the symbols as the self is said to be not to be done by you, the reasoning 'sa na' (he is not), which is characterized by the absence of identity, is stated.

original: sā tatrāpi brahmapratīkayorapi sameti hetoḥ pratīkeṣu brahmadṛṣṭiḥ kartavyeti sūtre
analyzed: sā tatra api brahma pratīkayoḥ api samā iti hetoḥ pratīkeṣu brahma dṛṣṭiḥ kartavyā iti sūtre
translated: That is also applicable to Brahman and the symbols. Therefore, when the aphorism is being explained that the view of Brahman in the symbols is to be done,

analyzed: vyākhyāyamāne sati ukta yukti viruddha tā bhavati iti
translated: the contradiction of the stated reasoning follows.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati  pratīkeṣu brahma dṛṣṭiḥ kartavyā iti sūtra vyākhyānam asat
translated: This is what is said.🔽The explanation of the aphorism that the view of Brahman in the symbols is to be done is not correct.

analyzed: pratīkam brahma tayā na upāsyam
translated: The symbol is not to be meditated upon as Brahman.

analyzed: a brahma tvāt
translated: Because it is not Brahman.

analyzed: yat yat na bhavati na tat tatvena upāsyam iti yukti viruddha tvāt
translated: If something is not Brahman, it is not to be meditated upon as Brahman. This is contradictory to reasoning.

analyzed: na ca iyam yuktiḥ apramā
translated: And this reasoning is not unestablished.

analyzed: pratīkānām ātma tvena upāsanasya a kartavya tāyām pūrva sūtre pareṇa eva upanyasta tvāt
translated: Because in the previous aphorism the opponent himself has brought forward the fact that the contemplation of the symbols as the Self is not to be done.

analyzed: anyathā anaikāntyena sādhikā na syāt
translated: Otherwise, it would not be a valid reason, as it would not be universal.

original: naca brahmapratīkayorabhedaḥ brahmaṇaḥ satyatvāt pratīkānāṃ kalpitatvāt /🔽pāramārthikabhedābhāvaḥ tāvadastīti cet /
analyzed: na ca brahma pratīkayoḥ abhedaḥ brahmaṇaḥ satya tvāt pratīkānām kalpita tvāt  pāramārthika bheda abhāvaḥ tāvat asti iti ced
translated: And the symbols are not identical with Brahman, because Brahman is real and the symbols are imagined.🔽If it be said that there is non-difference in the ultimate sense,

analyzed: tarhi jīva pratīkayoḥ api sa nā asti iti asiddhiḥ syāt iti
translated: then it would be an unestablished reason, as there is no such non-difference even between the individual soul and the symbols.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be the case.

original: nahi saḥ' / iti na nirviśeṣaṇo hetuḥ sūtrakārasyābhipreto
analyzed: nahi saḥ iti na nirviśeṣaṇaḥ hetuḥ sūtrakārasya abhipretaḥ
translated: For the reason is not intended by the author of the aphorisms to be without a qualification, as in 'it is not that'.

analyzed: mataḥ yena brahma dṛṣṭiḥ pratīkeṣu ukta yukti viruddhā syāt
translated: By which the contemplation of Brahman in the symbols would be contradicted by the reason stated.

analyzed: kim tu upāsyasya utkarṣa prāpti abhāve sati iti anena viśiṣyaḥ
translated: But rather with the qualification 'in the absence of the attainment of excellence of the object of contemplation'.

analyzed: pratīkānām brahmatvena upāsane tu utkarṣa prāptiḥ asti
translated: But in the contemplation of the symbols as Brahman, there is the attainment of excellence.

analyzed: tad bhāve pi upāsanā kāryā
translated: Therefore, even in the absence of that, the contemplation is to be done.

analyzed: yujyate iti atas āha yadi iti
translated: It is proper. Hence he says 'if'.

analyzed: yadi api utkarṣa mātreṇa hi a tad bhave pi upāsanā  ādye pi śabdaḥ tiprasaṅga samuccaya arthaḥ
translated: Even if it is only for the sake of excellence, in the absence of that, the contemplation is to be done.🔽In the first, the word 'api' (even) is for the purpose of including the absurdity.

analyzed: hi śabdasya uttara ardhena anvayaḥ
translated: The word 'hi' (for) is connected with the latter part.

analyzed: yadi viśiṣya hetum vyākhyāya pratīkānām atadbhāve brahmatve pi utkarṣa prāpti mātreṇa brahmatvena upāsanā aṅgīkriyate
translated: If, after explaining the reason for the distinction, it is accepted that the meditation on the symbols as Brahman is only for the sake of attaining superiority even in the absence of being Brahman,

analyzed: tadā ātma tvena api tad upāsanam aṅgīkāryam na tu nirākāryam
translated: then the meditation on them as the self should also be accepted, and not rejected.

analyzed: kutas iti atas āha utkarṣaḥ iti
translated: Why? To this he says superiority etc.

analyzed: utkarṣaḥ ātmanaḥ u pi syāt cetana tvāt acetanāt
translated: There would be superiority of the self also, because of being conscious, over the unconscious.

analyzed: yasmāt brahma vat ātmanaḥ pi pratīkāt utkarṣaḥ sti
translated: Because, like Brahman, the self also has superiority over the symbol.

analyzed: katham
translated: How?

analyzed: ātmanaḥ cetana tvāt
translated: Because the self is conscious.

analyzed: acetanam khalu pratīkam  tasya ātma tvena upāsanāyām utkarṣa praptiḥ syāt iti
translated: The symbol is indeed unconscious.🔽If it is meditated upon as the self, there would be attainment of superiority.

analyzed: atiprasaṅgasya viparyaya payarvasānam āha tasmāt iti
translated: He states the reductio ad absurdum of the opposite of the over-extension, saying therefore etc.

analyzed: na upāsyam iti veda vidaḥ matam
translated: Therefore, those who know the Veda consider that which is not the truth should not be meditated upon.

analyzed: yasmāt viśiṣya hetau vyākhyāyamāne pūrva sūtre siddhiḥ syāt
translated: Because, when the reason for the distinction is being explained in the previous aphorism, there would be non-establishment.

original: tata eva pratīkeṣu brahmopāsanavadātmopāsanaṃ ca prasajyeta /
analyzed: tatas eva pratīkeṣu brahma upāsana vat ātma upāsanam ca prasajyeta
translated: Therefore, just as there is meditation on Brahman in the symbols, so also meditation on the self would follow.

analyzed: tasmāt atattvam
translated: Therefore, that which is not the truth.

original: yadyanna bhavati tattatvena nopāsyamiti sāmānyameva sūtrakārasyābhimatam /
analyzed: yat yat na bhavati tat tatvena na upāsyam iti sāmānyam eva sūtrakārasya abhimatam
translated: If something does not exist, it should not be meditated upon as real - this is the general view of the author of the aphorisms.

analyzed: na tu viśeṣaṇa prakṣepaḥ
translated: But not the introduction of a qualification.

analyzed: tathā ca brahma dṛṣṭiḥ iti pratijñā sva ukta yukti viruddhā eva iti
translated: And so the assertion Brahman should be meditated upon is itself contradicted by the reasoning stated by him.

analyzed: atra vyāpteḥ nirviśeṣaṇa tva abhidhānasya hetoḥ nirviśeṣaṇa tve eva tātparyam
translated: Here, the reason because of the absence of a qualification in the statement of the pervasion is intended only to show the absence of a qualification.

analyzed: spaṣṭa tva artham tu vyāpti abhidhānam iti vācyam
translated: It should be said that the statement of the pervasion is for the sake of clarity.

analyzed: pratijñā vyākhyānam apākṛtya utkarṣāt iti hetu vyākhyānam apākaroti utkarṣāt iti
translated: Having refuted the explanation of the proposition, he refutes the explanation of the reason because of superiority with If the result...

analyzed: utkarṣāt brahma tā dhyāne yadi syāt phalam añjasā
translated: If the result were to be obtained directly from meditating on Brahman as superior,

analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ nīca tā dhyānāt anarthaḥ kim na jāyate
translated: why would misfortune not arise from meditating on Brahman as inferior?

original: brahmatādhyāne pratīkānāmutkarṣādutkarṣasya dṛṣṭatvādañjasā phalaṃ puruṣārtharūpaṃ phalaṃ yadi syāttadā /
analyzed: brahma tā dhyāne pratīkānām utkarṣāt utkarṣasya dṛṣṭa tvāt añjasā phalam puruṣa artha rūpam phalam yadi syāt tadā
translated: If the result, which is the human goal, were to be obtained directly from meditating on Brahman as superior, because superiority is seen to be superior in the meditation on symbols, then.

original: tadeva brahmaṇo nīcatādhyānamiti /🔽tasmādanarthaḥ kiṃ na jāyate /
analyzed: tat eva brahmaṇaḥ nīcatā dhyānam iti  tasmāt anarthaḥ kim na jāyate
translated: That very thing is meditating on Brahman as inferior.🔽Why would misfortune not arise from that?

analyzed: jāyate eva iti sama vyaya phala tvāt akāryam eva idam iti
translated: It arises indeed. Therefore, because the result is equal, this is not to be done.

analyzed: abhyupagamya idam sama vyaya phala tvam uktam
translated: This is said assuming that the result is equal to the cause.

original: vastutastu na puruṣārthaḥ kiṃ tvanartha evetyāha acetanasyeti //
analyzed: vastutas tu na puruṣa arthaḥ kim tu anarthaḥ eva iti āha acetanasya iti
translated: But in reality, it is not a human goal, but rather a calamity. Therefore he says:

analyzed: acetanasya brahmatva dhyāne tuṣyiḥ na hi kvacid
translated: In the meditation on the non-sentient Brahman, there is no satisfaction anywhere.

analyzed: nīcasya svātmatā dhyāne kupyati brahma loka vat
translated: In the meditation on the low as one's own self, Brahman becomes angry, as in the world.

analyzed: tuṣṭi aya bhāvāt ca na puruṣa artha lābhaḥ tatas
translated: And because there is no satisfaction, there is no attainment of human goal from that.

analyzed: kvacid iti anena yat acetanam tad upacikīrṣā lakṣaṇa tuṣyi rahitam iti vyāptim sūcayati
translated: By anywhere, he indicates the pervasion that whatever is non-sentient is devoid of satisfaction characterized by the desire to increase.

analyzed: nīcasya pratīkasya sva ātma tā dhyānāt brahma kupyati
translated: Brahman becomes angry due to the meditation on the low symbol as one's own self.

analyzed: tatas ca anartham prayacchati
translated: And then it bestows calamity.

analyzed: tatra dṛṣṭāntaḥ loka vat iti
translated: The example there is as in the world.

original: yathā loke śilādikaṃ rājatvādinā cintitaṃ na prasīdati nāpi puruṣārthaṃ prayacchati /
analyzed: yathā loke śilā ādikam rāja tva ādinā cintitam na prasīdati nā api puruṣa artham prayacchati
translated: Just as in the world, a stone etc. contemplated as a king etc. does not become pleased nor does it bestow human goal.

original: yathā ca rājā caṇḍālatvena dhyātaḥ kupyati anarthaṃ ca dadāti tathetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: yathā ca rājā caṇḍāla tvena dhyātaḥ kupyati anartham ca dadāti tathā iti arthaḥ
translated: And just as a king contemplated as a Chandala becomes angry and gives calamity, that is the meaning.

original: anena pratīkānāmacetanatve 'pi brahmaiva sarvādhyakṣatvātphalaṃ dāsyatīti ca pratyuktam /
analyzed: anena pratīkānām acetana tve brahmā eva sarva adhyakṣa tvāt phalam dāsyati iti ca pratyuktam
translated: By this, it is replied that even though the symbols are non-sentient, Brahman itself, being the overseer of all, will bestow the result.

analyzed: tasya anena upāsanena kupita tvāt
translated: Because of the anger caused by this meditation on it.

analyzed: na vayam brahmaṇi pratīka tva upāsanam brūmaḥ
translated: We do not say that Brahman should be meditated upon as an image,

original: yena brahma kupitamanarthaṃ prayacchet kintu pratīke brahmatvopāsanam /
analyzed: yena brahma kupitam anartham prayacchet kintu pratīke brahmatva upāsanam
translated: by which Brahman, if angry, would bestow misfortune. But rather that the image should be meditated upon as Brahman.

analyzed: tatas puruṣa artha prāptiḥ iti atas āha caṇḍālaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, the attainment of human goals. Hence he says: The Chandala and the King.

analyzed: caṇḍālaḥ nṛpaḥ iti ukte nṛpaḥ caṇḍālaḥ iti api
translated: When it is said The Chandala is the King and The King is the Chandala,

original: ko viśeṣaḥ parijñāte nṛpeṇa syāt kathañcana // / / //
analyzed: kaḥ viśeṣaḥ parijñāte nṛpeṇa syāt kathañcana
translated: what difference would there be if the King were to know it in any way?

original: caṇḍālamuddiśya caṇḍālo nṛpa ityukte tathā nṛpamuddiśya nṛpaścaṇḍāla ityukte nṛpeṇa parijñāte satyanarthaprāptau kathañcana ko viśeṣaḥ syānna
analyzed: caṇḍālam uddiśya caṇḍālaḥ nṛpaḥ iti ukte tathā nṛpam uddiśya nṛpaḥ caṇḍālaḥ iti ukte nṛpeṇa parijñāte sati anartha prāptau kathañcana kaḥ viśeṣaḥ syāt na
translated: When it is said The Chandala is the King referring to the Chandala, and The King is the Chandala referring to the King, if the King were to know it, what difference would there be in the attainment of misfortune in any way?

analyzed: kathañcitkaḥ pi
translated: In no way at all.

analyzed: atra ukta śabdena dhyānam upalakṣyate
translated: Here, the word said indicates meditation.

original: ajñātopāsano rājā nānarthaṃ karotīti nṛpeṇa parijñāta ityuktam /
analyzed: ajñāta upāsanaḥ rājā na anartham karoti iti nṛpeṇa parijñātaḥ iti uktam
translated: The unknown meditation on the King does not bring misfortune. Therefore, it is said if the King were to know it.

original: tathāca pratīkaṃ brahmetyupāsane brahma pratīkamityupāsane ca sama evānartha iti vākyaśeṣaḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca pratīkam brahma iti upāsane brahma pratīkam iti upāsane ca samaḥ eva anarthaḥ iti vākyaśeṣaḥ
translated: And thus, the remainder of the sentence is that there is the same misfortune in meditating on the image as Brahman and in meditating on Brahman as the image.

analyzed: nanu kṣattari rāja dṛṣṭiḥ phalavatī
translated: But the sight of the King in the Kshatriya is fruitful.

analyzed: rājñi kṣattṛ dṛṣṭiḥ anartha hetuḥ dṛṣṭā
translated: O Queen! The king's gaze is seen to be the cause of misfortune.

analyzed: tat katham ubhayasya sāmyam ucyate iti ced na
translated: If it is asked how the equality of both is stated, it is not so.

analyzed: tatra dṛṣṭeḥ abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no seeing there.

analyzed: ukti mātram tu upacāreṇa
translated: But the statement is by way of metaphor,

analyzed: siṃhaḥ devadattaḥ iti yathā
translated: like saying Devadatta is a lion.

analyzed: dṛṣṭau tu tatra api anartha sāmyam eva iti āśayena āha puratas iti
translated: But if there is seeing, then even there there is equality of misfortune. With this idea in mind, he says in front and so on.

analyzed: puratas naradevasya caṇḍālaḥ yadi pūjyate
translated: If a Chandala is worshipped in front of the king,

original: rājavat kiṃ na kopaḥ syād rājño loke hi paśyati // / / //
analyzed: rāja vat kim na kopaḥ syāt rājñaḥ loke hi paśyati
translated: like a king, why would there not be anger in the world, seeing as the king does?

analyzed: rājā yathā pūjyate tathā
translated: As the king is worshipped, so is he.

analyzed: tadā rājñaḥ kopaḥ na syāt kim
translated: Then why would there not be anger in the king?

analyzed: loke bhipaśyati satī iti kopa atiśaya pradarśana artham
translated: Seeing in the world is said to show the excess of anger.

analyzed: pūjayā darśanam unnīyate iti atas pūjyate iti uktam
translated: Since seeing is elevated by worship, it is said worshipped.

original: na kevalaṃ dṛṣṭerunnāyikāyāṃ pūjāyāmeva rājakopaḥ kintu tādṛśyāmuktāvapītyāha rājñastviti //
analyzed: na kevalam dṛṣṭeḥ unnāyikāyām pūjāyām eva rāja kopaḥ kintu tādṛśyām uktau api iti āha rājñaḥ tu iti
translated: It is not only the king's anger towards worship that elevates seeing, but also towards such a statement. He says of the king and so on.

original: rājñastu purataḥ prokte caṇḍālaṃ nṛpa ityapi /
analyzed: rājñaḥ tu puratas prokte caṇḍālam nṛpaḥ iti api
translated: When it is said in front of the king, The Chandala is the king,

analyzed: ātmānam saḥ iti proktam itivat hayā iva kupyati
translated: and I am he is said, he gets angry just as if it were said.

original: nājñātā proktiḥ kopajananītyato rājñastu purata ityuktam /
analyzed: na ajñātā proktiḥ kopa jananī iti atas rājñaḥ tu puratas iti uktam
translated: Not being known is a cause of anger, therefore it is said in the presence of the king.

original: caṇḍāle nṛpa iti prokte 'pi prakarṣeṇa na mayopacāreṇocyate api tu vastuta evetyukte 'pi rājā kupyatyeva hi /
analyzed: caṇḍāle nṛpaḥ iti prokte pi prakarṣeṇa na mayā upacāreṇa ucyate api tu vastutas evā iti ukte rājā kupyati eva hi
translated: Even when it is said the king is a Chandala, it is said I do not speak with flattery, but rather with the truth, the king still gets angry.

original: ātmānaṃ prati hi sa caṇḍāla iti proktaṃ prakarṣeṇoktamitivadityatra yathā tathaivetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: ātmānam prati hi sa caṇḍālaḥ iti proktam prakarṣeṇa uktam itivat iti atra yathā tathā eva iti arthaḥ
translated: For it is said he is a Chandala with respect to himself, meaning he is spoken of as superior. Here the meaning is just as it is said.

original: pūjaiva kopakāraṇaṃ na daśarnamityaśaṅkānirāsāya vivekārthamayaṃ ślokaḥ / /
analyzed: pūjā eva kopa kāraṇam na viveka artham ayam ślokaḥ
translated: Worship itself is the cause of anger, not seeing. To remove this doubt, this verse is for discrimination.

analyzed: evam uddeśa vidhāna uktayā dvairūpyam aṅgīkṛtya phalataḥ sāmyam uktam
translated: Thus, accepting the duality spoken of in the prescription of the topic, equality is stated in terms of result.

analyzed: idanīm tat api na asti iti āha abhedena iti
translated: Now, even that does not exist, he says in non-difference.

analyzed: abhede nā etayoḥ dhyāne kaḥ viśeṣaḥ vacasi api
translated: In the meditation of these two without difference, what difference is there even in speech?

original: etayorbrahmapratīkayorabhedena dhyāne 'ṅgīkṛte na kevalamanatharsāmyaṃ kintu vacasyāpi ko viśeṣaḥ /
analyzed: etayoḥ brahma pratīkayoḥ abhedena dhyāne ṅgīkṛte na kevalam anatha ṛsāmyam kintu vacasya api kaḥ viśeṣaḥ
translated: When the meditation of these two, Brahman and the symbol, is accepted without difference, not only is there equality of meaning, but what difference is there even in speech?

analyzed: vacana dvaya arthaḥ pya viśiṣyaḥ eva iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that even the meaning of the two statements is not distinguished.

analyzed: atra eva dṛṣṭāntam āha ayam iti
translated: Here itself, he gives an example, saying this.

original: ayaṃ rājā tvamityukte caṇḍāle 'tha nṛpe 'pi ca /
analyzed: ayam rājā tvam iti ukte caṇḍāle nṛpe ca
translated: If it is said that this is the king and you are that, or if it is said that this is a Chandala and that is a king,

original: caṇḍāla iti tu prokte samameva hi dūṣaṇam // / /f //
analyzed: caṇḍālaḥ iti tu prokte samam eva hi dūṣaṇam
translated: or if it is said that this is a Chandala and that is a Chandala, the fault is the same.

analyzed: vyakti bhedena dūṣaṇa parihāraḥ syāt iti atas yam iti uktam
translated: The objection is that the two are not different. The reply is that the fault is the same even if there is a difference in the individuals.

analyzed: dūṣaṇam nīcatva lakṣaṇam
translated: The fault is in the form of inferiority.

analyzed: dvayoḥ abhedena dhyāne dūṣaṇam sambhavati eva
translated: The fault is possible only if the two are meditated upon as non-different.

analyzed: na ca evam
translated: But this is not so.

analyzed: pratīkasya hi brahmatvam bhāvyate
translated: For the symbol is meditated upon as being Brahman.

original: natu brahmaṇaḥ pratīkatvamityata āha dhyāta iti //
analyzed: na tu brahmaṇaḥ pratīka tvam iti atas āha dhyātaḥ iti
translated: But Brahman is not meditated upon as being the symbol. Hence he says:

original: dhyāte tvekasya tadbhāve tadbhāvo 'nyasya kiṃ na tat // / / //
analyzed: dhyāte tu ekasya tad bhāve tad bhāvaḥ nyasya kim na tat
translated: If one is meditated upon as having that nature, why is not the other also so?

original: tattayorbrahmapratīkayorekasya pratīkasya tadbhāve brahmabhāve dhyāte satyanyasya brahmaṇastadbhāvaḥ pratīkabhāvaḥ dhyāto na kim / /
analyzed: tat tayoḥ brahma pratīkayoḥ ekasya pratīkasya tad bhāve brahma bhāve dhyāte sati anyasya brahmaṇaḥ tad bhāvaḥ pratīka bhāvaḥ dhyātaḥ na kim
translated: If one of the two, Brahman and the symbol, the symbol, is meditated upon as having that nature, as being Brahman, why is not the other, Brahman, meditated upon as having that nature, as being the symbol?

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati  bhavet ayam parihāraḥ yadi pratīkasya
translated: This is what is meant.

analyzed: sva rūpa upamardena tasya brahmatvam upāsyam iti pakṣaḥ syāt
translated: This reply would be correct if the view were that the symbol is to be meditated upon as Brahman, with the submergence of its own nature.

analyzed: na ca evam
translated: But this is not so.

analyzed: pratīka abhāva prasaṅgasya pareṇa eva ukta tvāt
translated: For the opponent himself has stated the absurdity that the symbol would cease to exist.

analyzed: bheda abheda abhiprāyeṇa ayam parihāraḥ iti api na asti
translated: Nor is this answer based on the intention of difference and non-difference.

original: nahi ghaṭo mṛdabhinno mṛdghaṭādbhinneti bhedābhedau kinnāma parasparam /
analyzed: nahi ghaṭaḥ mṛd abhinnaḥ mṛd ghaṭāt bhinnā iti bheda abhedau kinnāma parasparam
translated: For a pot is not different from clay, and clay is not different from a pot - how can there be difference and non-difference between them?

original: tasmādanupamarditasvarūpasya pratīkasya brahmatve dhyāte brahmaṇo 'pi pratīkatvaṃ dhyātameveti yuktamuktamiti /
analyzed: tasmāt anupamardita svarūpasya pratīkasya brahmatve dhyāte brahmaṇaḥ u pi pratīka tvam dhyātam eva iti yuktam uktam iti
translated: Therefore, when the form of the symbol, whose own nature is not destroyed, is meditated upon as Brahman, it is proper to say that Brahman is also meditated upon as a symbol.

analyzed: nanu asmin upāsane brahmaṇā jñāte narthaḥ syāt na tu ajñāte
translated: But in this meditation, if Brahman is known, there would be harm, not if it is not known.

original: atastathopāsanaṃ kariṣyata ityata āha na caiveti //
analyzed: atas tathā upāsanam kariṣyate iti atas āha na ca eva iti
translated: Therefore, one will perform meditation in that way. To this he says: And it is not so.

analyzed: na ca eva tat avijñātam sarvajña brahmaṇā kvacid
translated: And that meditation is never unknown to the omniscient Brahman.

analyzed: tat upāsanam
translated: That is meditation.

original: brahmaṇo 'jñāne sarvādhyakṣaṃ brahmaiva phalaṃ dāsyatīti riktaṃ vacaḥ syāt / /
analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ jñāne sarva adhyakṣam brahmā eva phalam dāsyati iti riktam vacaḥ syāt
translated: If Brahman is unknown, the statement that Brahman itself, the supervisor of all, will give the result, would be empty.

analyzed: nanu śruti vihitam ācaratā katham brahma kopena anartha prāptiḥ iti āśaṅkām pariharan apavyākhyāna nirākaraṇam upasaṃharati tasmāt iti
translated: But how can one who performs what is enjoined by the Vedas incur harm through Brahman's anger? Resolving this doubt, he concludes the refutation of the wrong explanation.

analyzed: tasmāt apeśalam sarvam anyasya brahma tā vacaḥ
translated: Therefore, all statements about another being Brahman are improper.

analyzed: sarvam iti śruti sūtra vyākhyāna rūpam
translated: All means in the form of explanations of the Vedas and aphorisms.

analyzed: etena sālagrāma ādau viṣṇu ādi pratipattiḥ api parāstā veditavyā

analyzed: dehaḥ cetanā dhiṣṭhitaḥ eva

analyzed: tata sraṣṭari

translated: The departure is from the body.🔽The meaning is that even before the departure of consciousness, the body of the created beings dissolves into the creators, from which it is produced.

analyzed: sraṣṭṛṣu laye nimittam sraṣṭuḥ grāsa bhūtasya iti

analyzed: devānām arciḥ ādi mārgaḥ na asti iti uktam tat kutas iti atas yat purā mārga antaram uktam tatas eva etat siddham iti āśayavān sta tanuvādena yuktaya antaram āha layāt ca iti

translated: Then, when it becomes the sphere of mind and speech, there is defilement by being the sphere of injunctions and prohibitions.

analyzed: rāga ādi doṣa saṃsargaḥ ca
translated: And there is association with faults such as passion.

analyzed: tatas deha indriya antaḥkaraṇa viṣaya sambandhe sthūlatara tā bhavati
translated: Then, in the connection with the body, senses, internal organ, and objects, there is a grosser state.

original: tato mamakāravato duḥkhādimattve sthūlatamattvamityevaṃ saṃvṛtyā tatkāryatvātsaṃvṛtisaṃjñakairahaṅkārādibhiśca saṃvalitaṃ śūnyameva saṃsāraḥ
analyzed: tatas mamakāravataḥ duḥkha ādimattve sthūlatama ttvam iti evam saṃvṛtyā tad kārya tvāt saṃvṛti saṃjñakaiḥ ahaṅkāra ādibhiḥ ca saṃvalitam śūnyam eva saṃsāraḥ
translated: Then, for one who has a sense of possession, there is the grossest state in the presence of suffering etc. Thus, samsara is just emptiness, enveloped by the ahamkara etc. called conventional, because they are the effects of that conventional [nature].

original: bhāvanāprakarṣādinā mūlasaṃvṛtau dhvastāyāṃ tatkāryapravāhe ca vilīne tadupalakṣitaṃ śūnyameva mokṣa iti / /
analyzed: bhāvanā prakarṣa ādinā mūla saṃvṛtau dhvastāyām tad kārya pravāhe ca vilīne tad upalakṣitam śūnyam eva mokṣaḥ iti
translated: And when the fundamental conventional [nature] is destroyed by the culmination of meditation etc., and when the stream of its effects is dissolved, liberation is just that emptiness indicated by that [conventional nature].

analyzed: śūnyam eva ced mokṣaḥ saṃsāraḥ ca
translated: If liberation and samsara are just emptiness,

original: tadā mokṣasaṃsāraśabdayoḥ paryāyatvamityādikamāpadyate ityetadapi codyamanenaiva parihṛtamityāśayavānāha saṃvṛtyaiveti //
analyzed: tadā mokṣa saṃsāra śabdayoḥ paryāya tvam iti ādikam āpadyate iti etat api codyam anena eva parihṛtam iti āśayavān āha saṃvṛtya eva iti
translated: then the words liberation and samsara become synonyms, and so on. This objection is also answered by this [verse]. With this intention, he says only by convention etc.

analyzed: saṃvṛtya eva viśeṣyate
translated: [It is said] only by convention [that it is distinguished].

analyzed: sthitayā dhvastayā ca eva saṃsṛtiḥ mokṣaḥ iti api
translated: Samsara and liberation are also distinguished by the existing and destroyed [convention] respectively.

analyzed: yadi api śūnyam eva saṃsāraḥ mokṣaḥ ca
translated: Even though samsara and liberation are just emptiness,

original: tathāpi saṃsṛtiriti mokṣa ityapi viśiṣyata eva /
analyzed: tathā api saṃsṛtiḥ iti mokṣaḥ iti api viśiṣyate eva
translated: nevertheless, samsara and liberation are distinguished.

analyzed: katham
translated: How?

analyzed: sthitayā ca dhvastayā ca saṃvṛtyā eva
translated: By the existing and destroyed convention only.

analyzed: upalakṣaṇa bhedāt artha bhede sati na śabda paryāya tva ādikam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that when there is a difference in meaning due to the difference in indication, there is no mere synonymity of words, etc.

analyzed: evam eka ātma vādam upanyasya aneka ātma vādam darśayati kecid iti
translated: Having thus presented the doctrine of one self, he shows the doctrine of many selves, saying some and so on.

analyzed: kecid teṣu anyathā prāhuḥ
translated: Some of them say otherwise among them.

analyzed: teṣu śūnyavādiṣu
translated: Among them, the proponents of emptiness.

analyzed: anyathā eka ātma vādi matāt
translated: Otherwise, from the doctrine of one self.

analyzed: katham iti atas āha saṃvṛtya eva iti
translated: How? To this he says only by convention and so on.

analyzed: saṃvṛtya eva tu anekadhā
translated: But only by convention in many ways.

analyzed: avacchinnam mahāśūnyam nānā na pudgala śabditam
translated: The great emptiness, limited, is called by the various names of pudgala.

analyzed: tuśabdena eka ātma vādam svābhāvika aneka ātma vādam upādhi kṛta aneka ātma vādam ca vyāvartayati
translated: By the word but, he excludes the doctrine of one self, the doctrine of many selves by nature, and the doctrine of many selves by adventitious attributes.

analyzed: saṃvṛtyā nānā bhūtayā saṃvṛtyā avacchinnam eva na tu svabhāvataḥ
translated: It is limited only by convention, by the many conventional realities, not by nature.

analyzed: saṃvṛteḥ tad kṛta avacchedānām ca mithyātvāt nānā pudgala śabditam iti uktam bhavati iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Because the convention and the limitations produced by it are false, it is said to be called by the various names of pudgala. The rest is understood.

analyzed: tatas kim iti atas āha yasya iti
translated: What then? To this he says of him and so on.

analyzed: yasya śūnya eka rasa tā jñānāt sā tu apagacchati
translated: For him, that [limitation] disappears by the knowledge of the oneness of taste with emptiness.

analyzed: sa pudgala tva nirmuktaḥ mahāśūnyatvam eṣyati
translated: He, being freed from pudgalatva, will attain the state of great emptiness.

analyzed: saṃvṛtya anyaḥ tu avacchinnaḥ duḥkhāni anubhavati alam
translated: But one who is limited by convention experiences various sorrows.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus...

analyzed: tatra anekeṣu ātmasu yasya ātmanaḥ tu śūnya eka rasa tā jñānāt śūnya advitīya tā jñānāt sā saṃvṛtiḥ apagacchati mūla saṃvṛtiḥ vyāvṛttā bhavati
translated: Among those many selves, for that self whose knowledge of emptiness is of the nature of emptiness alone, whose knowledge is of the nature of emptiness alone, that convention disappears, the fundamental convention is removed.

analyzed: anyā naśyati
translated: Another perishes.

analyzed: sa pudgala tvāt kartṛ tva ādi rūpāt nirmuktaḥ mahāśūnyatvam eṣyati iva
translated: He, being released from the form of an individual, an agent, and so on, will attain the state of great emptiness.

original: yastu saṃvṛtyāvacchinna ātmā sa pudgalabhāvena duḥkhānyalaṃ paramārthabuddhayaivānubhavati /
analyzed: yaḥ tu saṃvṛtya avacchinnaḥ ātmā sa pudgala bhāvena duḥkhāni alam paramārtha buddhayā eva anubhavati
translated: But the self that is limited by convention, he, as an individual, experiences sorrows abundantly by the knowledge of ultimate reality alone.

analyzed: iti prāhuḥ iti sambandhaḥ
translated: Thus they say - this is the connection.

analyzed: evam māyinaḥ ca āhuḥ eka jīva tva vādinaḥ
translated: Thus the illusionists also, who speak of the oneness of the individual soul,

analyzed: bahu jīva matāḥ ca iti
translated: and those who hold the doctrine of many individual souls,

original: śūnyavādyabhimatamokṣanirāsena māyāvādyabhimato 'pi nirasto bhaviṣyatītyāśayena yaduktaṃ māyino yatheti siddhāntasāmyaṃ tadupapādayati ityeevamiti
analyzed: śūnyavādi abhimata mokṣa nirāsena māyā vādi abhimataḥ api nirastaḥ bhaviṣyati iti āśayena yat uktam māyinaḥ yathā iti siddhānta sāmyam tat upapādayati iti
translated: With the intention that by refuting the liberation accepted by the proponents of emptiness, that accepted by the proponents of illusion will also be refuted, he explains the similarity of the conclusion by saying what the illusionists say, etc.

analyzed: eka jīva tva vādinaḥ bahu jīva matāḥ ca iti dvividha māyinaḥ ca evam dvividha śūnyavādi vat eva mokṣa svarūpam āhuḥ
translated: The illusionists of two kinds, those who speak of the oneness of the individual soul and those who hold the doctrine of many individual souls, speak of the nature of liberation in the same way as the two kinds of proponents of emptiness.

original: eko jīvo yasmiṃlloke sa tathoktastasya bhāvastattvaṃ tadvadantītyekajīvatvavādinaḥ /
analyzed: ekaḥ jīvaḥ yasmin loke sa tathā uktaḥ tasya bhāvaḥ tattvam tat vadanti iti eka jīva tva vādinaḥ
translated: Those who say that there is only one soul in the world are called Ekājīvatvavādins.

original: bahavo jīvā yasmiṃstattathoktaṃ bahujīvamataṃ yeṣāṃ te bahujīvamatāḥ / /
analyzed: bahavaḥ jīvāḥ yasmin tat tathā uktam bahu jīva matam yeṣām te bahu jīva matāḥ
translated: Those who hold the view that there are many souls are called Bahujīvamatas.

original: nanu śūnyavādinaḥ saṃvṛtinibandhanaḥ saṃsārastannivṛttiśca mokṣa ityācakṣate /
analyzed: nanu śūnyavādinaḥ saṃvṛti nibandhanaḥ saṃsāraḥ tad nivṛttiḥ ca mokṣaḥ iti ācakṣate
translated: Now, the proponents of the doctrine of emptiness say that worldly existence is based on conventional reality, and the cessation of that is liberation.

analyzed: māyā vādinaḥ tu māyā hetukaḥ yam saṃsāraḥ tad nivṛttiḥ ca mokṣaḥ iti
translated: But the proponents of the doctrine of illusion say that this worldly existence is caused by illusion, and the cessation of that is liberation.

analyzed: atas vaiṣamyam iti atas āha māyā iti
translated: Therefore, there is inequality. To this, he says māyā (illusion).

analyzed: māyā teṣām tu saṃvṛtiḥ
translated: But their māyā is the same as their conventional reality.

original: yā śūnyavādyabhyupagatā saṃvṛtiḥ saiva teṣāṃ māyināṃ māyā /
analyzed: yā śūnyavādi abhyupagatā saṃvṛtiḥ sā eva teṣām māyinām māyā
translated: That conventional reality accepted by the proponents of emptiness is the same as māyā for those proponents of illusion.

analyzed: anādya nirvācya tva lakṣaṇasya āvaraṇa vikṣepa ādeḥ kāryasya ca ekatvāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the characteristics of beginninglessness and inexplicability, and the effects such as obscuration and distraction, are the same.

analyzed: śūnya vādinaḥ śūnyam tattvam āhuḥ māyā vādinaḥ tu brahma
translated: The proponents of emptiness say that emptiness is the truth, but the proponents of the doctrine of illusion say that Brahman is.

original: ato 'sti vaiṣamyamityata āha nirviśeṣatveti //🔽nirviśeṣatvavācaiva śūnyaṃ brahmaiva no bhidā // / / //
analyzed: atas sti vaiṣamyam iti atas āha nirviśeṣa tva iti  nirviśeṣa tva vācā eva śūnyam brahma eva naḥ bhidā
translated: Therefore, there is inequality. To this, he says nirviśeṣatva (non-distinction).🔽By the very statement of non-distinction, there is no difference between emptiness and Brahman.

analyzed: śūnyam brahma iti ca etayoḥ bhidā no vidyate
translated: There is no difference between emptiness and Brahman.

analyzed: kutas nirviśeṣa tvasya vācā eva dvābhyām dvayoḥ nirviśeṣa tvena ukta tvāt
translated: Why? Because the absence of distinction is stated by the two statements as the absence of distinction between the two.

analyzed: vaidharmyam khalu vastunaḥ bhedakam
translated: For a difference in properties indeed distinguishes a thing.

analyzed: tat ca atra na asti iti dvayoḥ api sammatam
translated: And that does not exist here, so both agree that there is no difference between the two.

analyzed: atas śabda bheda mātram na vastu bhedaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, the mere difference in words does not make a difference in the thing.

analyzed: atha matam
translated: Now, if it is thought:

original: satyaṃ jñānamanantaṃ brahma vijñānamānandaṃ brahmaiveti śrutyaiva satyādilakṣaṇaṃ brahma sarvato vyāvartitaṃ tatkathaṃ śūnyaṃ brahmeti no bhidetyucyate
analyzed: satyam jñānam anantam brahma vijñānam ānandam brahma eva iti śrutyā eva satya ādi lakṣaṇam brahma sarvatas vyāvartitam tat katham śūnyam brahma iti no bhidā iti ucyate  /
translated: It is true, the Vedānta itself sets aside Brahman, which is real, knowledge, infinite, Brahman to be known, bliss, as Brahman, by all such attributes as reality, etc. How then can it be said that Brahman is non-different from the Void?

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

analyzed: satyam
translated: It is true.

analyzed: sat ādi lakṣaṇaiḥ brahma śrutyā sarvatas vyāvartitam iti
translated: Brahman is set aside by the Vedānta from all by such attributes as reality, etc.

analyzed: tat tu māyā vādi mate na upapadyate iti āśayavān āha sat iti
translated: But that is not possible in the doctrine of the Mādhyamikas, thus thinking, he says sat (reality), etc.

analyzed: saccit sukha ādikam ca eva kim kutas khaṇḍa vādinaḥ
translated: And how can there be reality, consciousness, bliss, etc. for one who advocates non-duality?

analyzed: sat ādikam ca kim eva na kim api iti arthaḥ
translated: And how can there be reality, etc. means there can be nothing at all.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: For thus:

analyzed: sat ādikam kim brahma svarūpam uta anyat
translated: Is reality, etc. the nature of Brahman or something else?

analyzed: ādye na lakṣya lakṣaṇa bhāvaḥ
translated: In the first case, there is no relation of definition and definendum.

analyzed: aneka pada vaiyarthyam ca
translated: And there is the uselessness of many words.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: Not the second,

analyzed: akhaṇḍa vādi tvāt
translated: because of advocating non-duality.

original: yathā bhavatāṃ satyatvādikaṃ brahmasvarūpamapi tallakṣaṇaṃ tathā mamāpi kiṃ na syāditi cenna /
analyzed: yathā bhavatām satya tva ādikam brahma svarūpam api tad lakṣaṇam tathā mama api kim na syāt iti ced na
translated: If it be asked, why should not the nature of Brahman, such as its truth, &c., be the definition of it as well as of yours? we reply, no;

analyzed: asmābhiḥ viśeṣa śaktayā tad nirvāha aṅgīkārāt
translated: because we admit that it is accomplished by a special power.

analyzed: pareṇa tu kutas nirvāhyam etat
translated: But how can the other party accomplish it?

analyzed: mayā api viśeṣaḥ ṅgīkriyate iti ced na
translated: If it be said that we also admit a special power, no;

analyzed: akhaṇḍa vādi tvāt
translated: because we maintain the doctrine of the absolute unity of Brahman.

original: yadyapi satyādipadapratipādyavastuni na bhedaḥ /🔽tathāpi vyāvartyānāmasattvādīnāmastyeva atastadvayāvṛttiprayojanāni tadvācīni vānekāni
analyzed: yadi api satya ādi pada pratipādya vastuni na bhedaḥ  tathā api vyāvartyānām asattva ādīnām asti eva atas tad vayāvṛtti prayojanāni tad vācīni vā anekāni
translated: Although there is no difference in the thing denoted by the words truth, &c.,🔽yet there is a difference in the things excluded by them, such as untruth, &c.; and so we admit that there are many words denoting those things, which are used with reference to Brahman, in order to exclude those things.

original: padāni brahmaṇi vartanta ityabhyupagamātkathamasmanmate śrutyarthānirvāha ityata āha vyāvartyeti //
analyzed: padāni brahmaṇi vartante iti abhyupagamāt katham asmad mate śruti artha anirvāhaḥ iti atas āha vyāvartya iti
translated: How then can the meaning of the Vedānta texts be accomplished according to our doctrine? To this he says:

analyzed: vyāvartya mātra bhedaḥ tu vidyate śūnyavādinaḥ
translated: The doctrine of the Buddhist, that there is a difference only in the things excluded,

analyzed: vyāvartya mātra bhedaḥ tu iti eka deśa utkīrtanena sakalam api uktam upalakṣayati
translated: By the mention of a part, the doctrine of the Buddhist, that there is a difference only in the things excluded, indicates the whole doctrine.

original: eṣā prakriyā samastā śūnyavādino 'pi mate 'styevāto naitayāpi brahmaśūnyayorbhedo vaktuṃ śakyate /
analyzed: eṣā prakriyā samastā mate sti eva atas na etayā api brahma śūnyayoḥ bhedaḥ vaktum śakyate
translated: This whole process is found in the doctrine of the Buddhist also; and so it cannot be said that Brahman and the void are different by this process also.

analyzed: vidyate iti kim āpādanena ucyate
translated: Even for the proponent of emptiness, it exists. What is the point of arguing?

analyzed: na iti āha anṛta ādeḥ iti
translated: He says no, with of untruth, etc.

analyzed: anṛta ādeḥ apoham tu svayam eva hi manyate
translated: But he himself thinks that the exclusion of untruth, etc.

analyzed: satya ādi padārtha tvena śūnya viśeṣaṇa tvena ca iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is: as the meaning of the words truth, etc., and as the qualification of emptiness.

analyzed: manyate śūnya vādī
translated: The proponent of emptiness thinks.

analyzed: apoha padārtha vādinaḥ bauddhāḥ iti prasiddham eva iti hi śabdena āha
translated: That the Buddhists, who propound the meaning of exclusion, are well-known, he says with the word indeed.
Which is opposed to the previous faults of dullness, concealment, and suffering,

analyzed: iti prasiddham ca
translated: and it is well-known.

analyzed: āstām tāvat brahma śūnyayoḥ viśeṣa pratipādanam nirviśeṣayoḥ
translated: Let alone the teaching of the difference between Brahman and emptiness, of the two which are without distinctions.

analyzed: viśeṣaḥ asti iti pratijñā eva tāvat eṣā na aṅgam dhatte
translated: The proposition itself, that there is a distinction, does not hold.

analyzed: vyāhata tvāt iti bhāvena āha nirviśeṣa tvataḥ iti
translated: With the thought that it is contradictory, he says because of being without distinctions, etc.

analyzed: nirviśeṣa tvataḥ nā eva viśeṣaḥ brahma śūnyayoḥ
translated: Because of being without distinctions, there is no distinction between Brahman and emptiness.

analyzed: na eva pratijñātum śakyate iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is: it cannot be asserted at all.

original: nanu māyāvādinā vedasya prāmāṇyaṃ svataḥ prāmāṇyaṃ nityatvaṃ cāṅgīkṛtya vedavākyanirvāho 'yaṃ kṛtaḥ /
analyzed: nanu māyā vādinā vedasya prāmāṇyam svatas prāmāṇyam nitya tvam ca aṅgīkṛtya veda vākya nirvāhaḥ yam kṛtaḥ
translated: But the Mimamsaka has established the validity of the Veda by accepting the self-validity and eternality of the Veda.

analyzed: śūnyavādī tu veda prāmāṇyam eva na aṅgīkurute
translated: But the proponent of emptiness does not even accept the validity of the Veda.

analyzed: tat katham uktam vyāvartya mātrā iti
translated: How then is it said to be merely a reversal?

analyzed: tatra āha prāmāṇya ādi iti
translated: To that he says authoritativeness and so on.

original: prāmāṇyādi ca vedasya phalataḥ samameva hi // / / //
analyzed: prāmāṇya ādi ca vedasya phalataḥ samam eva hi
translated: And the authoritativeness etc. of the Veda is indeed equally fruitful.

analyzed: śabda mātreṇa viṣamam
translated: It is unequal by mere word.

analyzed: arthaḥ tu dvayoḥ api samaḥ eva
translated: But the meaning is the same for both.

analyzed: tasmāt vākya artha nirvāhaḥ samaḥ iti uktam upapannam
translated: Therefore, the fulfillment of the meaning of the sentence is also equal. Thus it is said to be reasonable.

original: vedavākyapuraskārastu māyāvādināṃ chadmamātraṃ prameyaṃ tu samānameveti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: veda vākya puraskāraḥ tu māyā vādinām chadma mātram prameyam tu samānam eva iti bhāvaḥ
translated: But the placing of the Vedic sentence at the forefront by the Mādhyamikas is mere pretense. The object of knowledge is the same for both. This is the idea.

analyzed: katham phalataḥ samānam iti atas āha a tattva āvedakam iti
translated: How is it equally fruitful? To this he says because it does not reveal reality and so on.

analyzed: a tattva āvedakam yasmāt pramāṇam tena kathyate
translated: Because it is said that a means of valid knowledge which does not reveal reality

analyzed: vedaḥ iti vartate
translated: is the Veda. This is the meaning.

analyzed: sarvam api pramāṇam iti vā
translated: Or all means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: tena māyā vādinā
translated: By that, by the Mādhyamikas.

original: kathyate avidyāvadviṣayāṇi pratyakṣādīni pramāṇāni śāstrāṇi cetyādāviti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: kathyate avidyāvat viṣayāṇi pratyakṣa ādīni pramāṇāni śāstrāṇi ca ityādau iti śeṣaḥ
translated: It is said that the means of valid knowledge such as perception etc. and the scriptures have as their objects those who are subject to ignorance. This is the remainder.

original: atattvāvedakatve 'ṅgīkṛte 'pi kutaḥ samamityata āha atattvāvedakatvamiti // /🔽atattvāvedakatvaṃ yadaprāmāṇyaṃ satāṃ matam // / / //
analyzed: atattva āvedaka tve ṅgīkṛte pi kutas samam iti atas āha atattva āvedaka tvam iti  atattva āvedaka tvam yat aprāmāṇyam satām matam
translated: Even if the non-revealing of reality is accepted, how is it equal? To this he says the non-revealing of reality and so on.🔽The non-revealing of reality which is considered by the wise to be invalidity🔽is the reason.

analyzed: yat yasmāt satām viduṣām
translated: Because of that, by the wise, by the learned.

original: nānāvidhāni lakṣaṇāni praṇayanto 'pi parīkṣakā atattvāvedakavyāvṛttaye prayatanta eva /🔽anubhūtiḥ pramāṇamiti vadatāpyatattvāvedakābhāvābhimānenaiva na prayatnaḥ kṛtaḥ /
analyzed: nānāvidhāni lakṣaṇāni praṇayantaḥ pi parīkṣakāḥ a tattva āvedaka vyāvṛttaye prayatantaḥ eva  anubhūtiḥ pramāṇam iti vadatā api a tattva āvedaka abhāva abhimānena eva na prayatnaḥ kṛtaḥ
translated: Even while formulating various definitions, the investigators are indeed striving only to exclude what does not convey reality.🔽Even one who says that experience is the means of valid knowledge has not made an effort merely by the conviction that it does not convey what is not real.

analyzed: na punar a tattva āvedakasya api prāmāṇya abhiprāyeṇa
translated: But not with the intention that even what conveys what is not real is a means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: atas māyā vādinā abhyupagatam veda prāmāṇyam nāma aprāmāṇyam eva
translated: Therefore, the so-called validity of the Veda accepted by the Mimamsakas is actually invalid.

analyzed: prāmāṇya abhāve ca tad svatastvam dūra utsāritam
translated: And when there is absence of validity, its intrinsic nature is far removed.

analyzed: nitya tva vyutpādanam ca vyartham eva iti
translated: And the explanation of its eternality is pointless.

original: nanvatattvāvedakatve 'pi yasya viṣayo brahmajñānātprāgeva bādhyate tadapramāṇam /
analyzed: nanu atattva avedaka tve pi yasya viṣayaḥ brahma jñānāt prāk eva bādhyate tat apramāṇam
translated: But even if it conveys what is not real, that which has an object that is contradicted even before the knowledge of Brahman is not a means of valid knowledge.

original: yasya tu viṣayo brahmajñānenaiva bādhyastadatattvāvedakaṃ pramāṇamiti vibhāgaḥ /
analyzed: yasya tu viṣayaḥ brahma jñānena eva bādhyaḥ tad atattva āvedakam pramāṇam iti vibhāgaḥ
translated: But that which has an object that is contradicted only by the knowledge of Brahman is a means of valid knowledge that conveys what is not real.

analyzed: veda viṣayaḥ tu brahma jñānena eva bādhyate  atas tasya prāmāṇyam iti āśayena āśaṅkate dīrgha iti
translated: But the object of the Veda is contradicted only by the knowledge of Brahman.🔽Therefore, with the idea that it is a means of valid knowledge, he raises the objection with the word long (in the verse).

analyzed: dīrgha bhrānti karī ced syāt a tattva āvedaka pramā
translated: If it were to cause a long error, it would be a means of valid knowledge that conveys what is not real.

original: yā dīrghabhrāntikarī sātattvāvedakaprameti yadi mataṃ syādityarthaḥ /
analyzed: yā dīrgha bhrānti karī sā a tattva āvedaka pramā iti yadi matam syāt iti arthaḥ
translated: If it is thought that which causes long-standing error is a valid cognition revealing reality, that is the meaning.

analyzed: kim idam loka vṛttam anusṛtya ucyate
translated: Is this said following worldly practice?

analyzed: kim vā sva saṅketa mātreṇa  ādye doṣam āha rajju iti
translated: Or by one's own mere convention?🔽In the first case, he states the fault with rope etc.

analyzed: rajju sarpa ādi vijñānāt api ādhikyāt amāna tā
translated: It would be more despised than even the cognition of a snake in a rope,

analyzed: syāt āgamasya a nivartya mahā moha prada tvataḥ
translated: because the scripture would give rise to a great delusion that cannot be averted.

analyzed: āgamasya vedasya
translated: Of the scripture, the Veda.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why?

analyzed: alpena kālena anivartya tvāt yaḥ mahān mohaḥ tad prada tvataḥ
translated: Because it cannot be averted in a short time, because it gives rise to a great delusion.

analyzed: aprāmāṇye viśeṣa abhāve pi tad hetuka anartha atiśaya abhiprāyeṇa ādhikyāt iti uktam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that although there is no difference in invalidity, it is said to be more because of the intention of the excess of harm caused by it.

analyzed: dvitīye atiprasaṅgam āha tala iti
translated: In the second case, he states the absurdity with flatness etc.

analyzed: tala nailya ādi vijñānam ākāśe māna tām vrajet
translated: The cognition of flatness on the ground would attain validity in space.

analyzed: talam indranīlam tasya nailyam iva nailyam tala nailyam
translated: The ground is sapphire, and its blueness is like the blueness of the ground.

analyzed: ādi pada artham svayam eva bhāṣyakṛt vivṛṇoti chatra iti
translated: The author of the commentary himself explains the meaning of etc. with umbrella etc.

analyzed: chatra ākāra tva vijñānam candra prādeśa tā matiḥ  ākāśaḥ iti vartate
translated: And the cognition of the shape of an umbrella is the notion of the size of the moon.🔽In space is to be supplied everywhere.

analyzed: māna tām vrajet iti sarvatra sambaddhayate
translated: Would attain validity is to be supplied everywhere.

original: alpakālānivartyabhrāntihetoḥ prāmāṇyasaṅketaṃ kurvatā eteṣāmapi prāmāṇyasaṅketaḥ karaṇīyo 'viśeṣāt /
analyzed: alpa kāla anivartya bhrānti hetoḥ prāmāṇya saṅketam kurvatā eteṣām api prāmāṇya saṅketaḥ karaṇīyaḥ viśeṣāt
translated: For one who makes the convention of validity for the cause of error that is not removed for a short time, the convention of validity for these also should be made, because there is no distinction.

original: brahmajñānanivartyaviṣayatvamāśrityāyaṃ saṅketaḥ kriyate na tvalpakālānivartyabhrāntihetutvamiti cet /
analyzed: brahma jñāna nivartya viṣaya tvam āśritya ayam saṅketaḥ kriyate na tu alpa kāla anivartya bhrānti hetutvam iti ced
translated: If it is argued that this convention is made relying on the object to be removed by the knowledge of Brahman, not on the cause of error that is not removed for a short time,

analyzed: na brahma jñāna nivartya viṣa tva uktayā api asya eva arthasya māyāvādinā vivakṣita tvāt
translated: it is not so, because the same meaning is intended by the proponent of illusion by stating the object to be removed by the knowledge of Brahman.

original: anyathāna khalu nāga iti naga iti vā padātkuñjaraṃ giriṃ vā pratipadyamānā bhavanti bhrāntā' /
analyzed: anyathā na khalu nāgaḥ iti nagaḥ iti vā padāt kuñjaram girim vā pratipadyamānāḥ bhavanti bhrāntāḥ
translated: Otherwise, indeed, when one understands an elephant or a mountain from the words nāga or naga, one does not become deluded.

analyzed: iti varṇa dairghya ādi jñānam katham udāharet
translated: So how can one cite the knowledge of the length of a vowel, etc.?

original: kiṃ caivaṃvidhaṃ vedaprāmāṇyaṃ śūnyavādināpyaṅgīkṛtameveti kuto 'yaṃ viśeṣaḥ /
analyzed: kim ca evaṃvidham veda prāmāṇyam śūnyavādinā api aṅgīkṛtam evā iti kutas yam viśeṣaḥ
translated: Moreover, such validity of the Veda is accepted even by the proponent of emptiness. So what is the difference?

analyzed: na sarvasya api vedasya māyā vādinā a tattva avedaka tvam ucyate
translated: Not all of the Veda is said by the proponent of illusion to be non-revealing of reality.

analyzed: kim nāma vidhi pratiṣedha viṣayasya
translated: Rather, it is said of that which is the content of injunctions and prohibitions.

analyzed: advitīyam tattvam pratipādayataḥ tat tvam asi ityādeḥ mahāvākyasya nirviśeṣam saccidānanda ātmakam tad padārtham pratipādayataḥ yat tat adreśyam agrāhyam satyam
translated: The great sentences like 'That thou art' which teach the non-dual Reality, and which teach the meaning of the word 'tat' as pure existence, consciousness and bliss, that which is invisible and ungraspable, is the Truth.

analyzed: ityādeḥ avāntaravākyasya ca tattva āvedaka tvam aṅgīkriyate eva
translated: Since the great sentence That thou art etc. teaches the non-dual truth, and the subordinate sentence That which is unseen, ungraspable, true, one without a second etc. teaches the reality which is Brahman, consisting of existence, knowledge and bliss, free from distinctions, it is indeed accepted that they teach the truth.

analyzed: na ca evam śūnyavādinā
translated: And the followers of the doctrine of emptiness do not accept this.

analyzed: ityatas katham sāmyam ityatas śūnyavādinā api evam eva aṅgīkriyate
translated: Therefore, how can there be similarity? Hence, the followers of the doctrine of emptiness also accept this.

analyzed: tattva āvedaka tvam hi na viṣaya visaṃvāda abhāva atiriktam kiñcid asti
translated: For, teaching the truth is nothing but the absence of contradiction with the object.

analyzed: vākya dvaya arthasya ca avisaṃvādaḥ śūnyavādinā api aṅgīkṛta
translated: And the non-contradiction of the meaning of the two sentences is accepted even by the followers of the doctrine of emptiness.

analyzed: kriyate eva iti āśayavān mahāvākya artha aṅgīkāram tāvat darśayati nirbheda tvam tu iti
translated: With this intention, he first shows the acceptance of the meaning of the great sentence: But the absence of distinctions in emptiness is always accepted by them.

analyzed: nirbheda tvam tu śūnyasya tena api aṅgīkṛtam sadā
translated: But the absence of distinctions in emptiness is always accepted by them.

analyzed: tena śūnyavādinā api
translated: By them, he means even by the followers of the doctrine of emptiness.

analyzed: sadā iti anena svayam eva na asmad āpādanena iti sūcayati
translated: By always, he indicates that it is accepted by themselves, not by our argument.

original: avāntaravākyārthāṅgīkāro 'pi dvayoḥ samāna iti darśayannirviśeṣatvaṃ tāvadubhayasammatamityāha sattveti //
analyzed: avāntara vākya artha aṅgīkāraḥ pi dvayoḥ samānaḥ iti darśayan nirviśeṣa tvam tāvat ubhaya sammatam iti āha sattva iti
translated: He shows that the acceptance of the meaning of the intermediate sentences is the same for both. First, he says that non-distinction is accepted by both, with existence and so on.

analyzed: sattva asattva ādi dharmāṇām abhāvaḥ ubhayoḥ mataḥ
translated: The non-existence of attributes such as existence and non-existence is accepted by both.

analyzed: tattvasya iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is of reality.

analyzed: ubhayoḥ māyāvādi śūnyavādinoḥ mataḥ sammataḥ
translated: It is accepted, agreed upon, by both the Mādhyamika and the Śūnyavāda.

analyzed: satya tvam api
translated: Existence is also

original: śūnyavādināṅgīkriyata ityāśayena śūnyaṃ nāmāsattasya sattvaṃ kathamityata āha nahīti //
analyzed: śūnyavādinā aṅgīkriyate iti āśayena śūnyam nāma asattasya sattvam katham iti atas āha nahi iti
translated: accepted by the Śūnyavādin. With this in mind, he says how can non-existence be existence and so on.

original: na hi satpratiyogitvaṃ śūnyatvaṃ tena ceṣyate // / / //
analyzed: na hi sat pratiyogi tvam śūnyatvam tena ca iṣyate
translated: For non-existence is not accepted by him as the existence of an existent.

analyzed: sat pratiyogi tvam sat virodhi tvam asattvam
translated: Non-existence is the existence of an existent, the contradiction of an existent, non-existence.

analyzed: tena ca śūnyavādinā api
translated: By that, even by the Śūnyavādin.

analyzed: nirviśeṣa tva abhiprāyeṇa śūnyam iti ucyate na asattva abhiprāyeṇa
translated: It is said to be empty with the intention of non-distinction, not with the intention of non-existence.

analyzed: tattvam iti aṅgīkārāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that it is accepted as reality.

original: ānandatāpi śūnyavādinā abhyupagamyata iti vaktuṃ māyāvādyabhyupagatānandatāṃ tāvadanuvadati naceti //
analyzed: ānanda tā api śūnyavādinā abhyupagamyate iti vaktum māyā vādi abhyupagata ānanda tām tāvat anuvadati na ca iti
translated: In order to say that even the state of bliss is accepted by the Śūnyavādin, he first repeats the state of bliss accepted by the Mādhyamika, with and bliss is not accepted as anything other than the contradiction of suffering.

analyzed: na ca duḥkha virodhi tvāt anyā hi ānanda tā iṣyate
translated: And bliss is not accepted as anything other than the contradiction of suffering.🔽By the Mādhyamika.

analyzed: māyinā
translated: The magician...🔽...

analyzed: duḥkha virodhi tvam eva ānanda tvam natu dharma rūpam kim api iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the state of being bliss is just the state of being opposed to suffering, and not some property of Brahman.

analyzed: hi śabdena anṛta jaḍa virodhi ityādi tad prasiddhim sūcayati
translated: By the word indeed, he indicates its well-known meaning, such as being opposed to untruth and inertness, etc.

analyzed: tatas kim iti atas āha śūnya iti
translated: What follows from that? To this he says in the case of emptiness, etc.

analyzed: śūnya pakṣe pi
translated: Even in the case of the doctrine of emptiness, etc.

analyzed: tad samānam iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is that is the same.

analyzed: jāḍya saṃvṛti duḥkhānta pūrva doṣa virodhi yat
translated: That which is opposed to inertness, concealment, suffering, and the previous faults, etc.

analyzed: ityādi tad vacanāt
translated: This is because of those statements.

analyzed: jñāna tva aṅgīkāram darśayati jñānam iti
translated: He shows the acceptance of the nature of knowledge by saying knowledge, etc.

analyzed: jñānam jāḍya virodhi ca
translated: Knowledge is opposed to inertness, etc.

analyzed: jñānam ca jāḍya virodhi svarūpam evā ucyate māyinā
translated: The Mãyâvâdins say that knowledge has the nature of being opposed to inertness.

analyzed: tat śūnyavādinaḥ u pi samānam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that this is the same for the proponents of emptiness also.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

original: māyāvādinā brahmaṇo nirviśeṣatvādikamaṅgīkriyate śūnyavādinā tu śūnyasya /
analyzed: māyā vādinā brahmaṇaḥ nirviśeṣa tva ādikam aṅgīkriyate śūnyavādinā tu śūnyasya
translated: The Mãyâvâdins accept Brahman to be without distinctions, etc., but the proponents of emptiness accept emptiness.

analyzed: tat katham sāmyam iti atas mā evam
translated: How then is there similarity? To this he says no,🔽because the non-difference of Brahman and emptiness has been stated.

analyzed: brahma śūnyayoḥ bheda abhāvasya ukta tvāt iti āha dharmāḥ iti
translated: He says no distinctions, etc.

original: dharmāḥ ke 'pi na santyeva ko viśeṣastatastayoḥ // / / //
analyzed: dharmāḥ ke pi na santi eva kaḥ viśeṣaḥ tatas tayoḥ
translated: No distinctions at all exist, so what distinction is there between them?

original: tato vyāvartakābhāvāttayorbrahmaśūnyayoḥ ko viśeṣaḥ kiṃkṛto bhedaḥ syāt /
analyzed: tatas vyāvartaka abhāvāt tayoḥ brahma śūnyayoḥ kaḥ viśeṣaḥ kiṃkṛtaḥ bhedaḥ syāt
translated: Then, in the absence of any distinction, what difference can there be between the two, Brahman and the Void? What is the basis of the distinction?

analyzed: nanu ukta vidham advaita tattvam sūtrakārasya siddhāntaḥ eva
translated: But has not the author of the aphorisms established the truth of non-duality in the very manner stated above?

original: tatkathaṃ dūṣaṇāya tadanuvādaḥ kriyata ityata āha etādṛśānāmiti //
analyzed: tat katham dūṣaṇāya tad anuvādaḥ kriyate iti atas āha etādṛśānām iti
translated: How then is that truth stated by him for the purpose of refutation? In answer to this he says:

analyzed: etādṛśānām pakṣāṇām dūṣaṇam prabhurā kṛtam
translated: The Lord has refuted such positions

analyzed: sva pakṣa sādanena eva
translated: By the establishment of his own position.

analyzed: śūnyapakṣa sadṛśa pakṣāṇām
translated: Of positions similar to the doctrine of the Void.

analyzed: katham
translated: How?

analyzed: tad viruddhasya sva pakṣasya sādhanena eva arthāt
translated: By the establishment of his own position, which is contrary to the doctrine of the Void.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is meant.

analyzed: na advaitam sūtrakārasya siddhāntaḥ
translated: Non-duality is not the established doctrine of the author of the aphorisms.

analyzed: tena tasya dūṣita tvāt
translated: Because it has been refuted by him.

original: pṛthagupadeśādityādinā tadviruddhātharsya sādhitatvāt /🔽nahi tasya duṣyatāmananusandadhattadviruddhaṃ sādhayatīti sambhavatīti /
analyzed: pṛthak upadeśāt ityādinā sādhita tvāt  nahi tasya duṣyatām an anusandadhat tat viruddham sādhayati iti sambhavati iti
