analyzed: tatra āhuḥ
translated: There they say...

analyzed: tatra muktau icchā dveṣa prayatna ādeḥ api layam āhuḥ
translated: There, regarding the liberated one, they say there is dissolution even of desire, aversion, effort, and so on.

analyzed: supti pralaya vailakṣaṇyam darśayitum sarva ātmanā iti uktam
translated: Completely is stated to show the difference from sleep and dissolution.

analyzed: nivṛtta jātīyasya tasmin eva ātmani punar anutpādaḥ sarva ātmanā layaḥ
translated: The dissolution of the person of the nature of the effect into the same Self is the non-rebirth of one who has ceased to be of the nature of the effect.

analyzed: ādi padena buddhi duḥkha dharma adharmāṇām śarīra indriyāṇām ca grahaṇam
translated: By the word 'etc.' are included the intellect, pain, merit and demerit, and the body and senses.

analyzed: tatas ca ayam āśayaḥ
translated: And this is the intention.

analyzed: na tāvat muktasya sukham anādi iti upapadyate
translated: First, it is not reasonable that the bliss of the liberated one is beginningless.

original: saṃsāre 'pi tatpratibhāsaprasaṅgāt pratibhāsata eveti cenna /🔽pratibhāsamānasyānāditāyāṃ sādhanopādānavaiyarthyāpatteḥ /
analyzed: saṃsāre pi tad pratibhāsa prasaṅgāt pratibhāsate eva iti ced na  pratibhāsamānasya anādi tāyām sādhana upādāna vaiyarthya āpatteḥ
translated: If it is argued that it appears even in saṃsāra because it appears, it is not so.🔽Because if what appears is beginningless, the effort to prove it is pointless.

original: avyaktatvātsaṃsāre na pratibhāsate vyaktatvāttu muktau pratibhāsata iti cenna /
analyzed: avyakta tvāt saṃsāre na pratibhāsate vyakta tvāt tu muktau pratibhāsate iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that it does not appear in saṃsāra because it is unmanifest, but it appears in liberation because it is manifest, it is not so.

analyzed: avyaktiḥ hi pratibhāsa abhāvaḥ vyaktiḥ ca pratibhāsaḥ
translated: For unmanifestness is the absence of appearance, and manifestness is appearance.

original: tataścāpratibhāsānna pratibhāsate pratibhāsanācca pratibhāsata ityuktaṃ syāt /
analyzed: tatas ca apratibhāsāt na pratibhāsate pratibhāsanāt ca pratibhāsate iti uktam syāt
translated: Therefore, it would be said that it does not appear because it does not appear, and it appears because it appears.

analyzed: kiñca pratīti kāraṇa antaḥkaraṇa sadbhāve saṃsāre na pratīyate
translated: Moreover, it is well said that it does not appear in saṃsāra when the internal organ, the cause of cognition, exists,

original: muktau tu tadapagame pratīyata iti subhāṣitam /
analyzed: muktau tu tad apagame pratīyate iti subhāṣitam
translated: but it appears in liberation when that ceases.

analyzed: āvṛta tvāt na pratīyate iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that it does not appear because it is covered, it is not so.

analyzed: mūrta tva abhāvena āvaraṇa anupapatteḥ
translated: Because covering is not possible due to the absence of materiality.

analyzed: tad anirūpaṇāt ca
translated: And because that [pleasure] is not determined.

analyzed: sukham iva tad pratītiḥ api anādiḥ ced kim āvaraṇa kṛtyam
translated: If the cognition of that [pleasure] is beginningless like pleasure, what function does an obscuration have?

analyzed: viṣaya viṣayi bhāvaḥ pratibadhyate iti ced na
translated: If it is said that the relation of object and subject is obstructed, that is not so.

analyzed: nirviṣayāyāḥ pratīteḥ anupapatteḥ
translated: Because a cognition without an object is not possible.

analyzed: sukha tad pratītyoḥ anāditāyām pramitāyām eva ca eṣā kalpanā yuktā
translated: And when the beginninglessness of pleasure and its cognition is established, this imagination is appropriate.

analyzed: na ca tatra pramāṇam paśyāmaḥ
translated: And we do not see any means of knowledge in that [case].

analyzed: tatas sukhasya tad pratīteḥ ca muktau utpattiḥ eva vaktavyā
translated: Therefore, it must be said that pleasure and its cognition arise in liberation.

analyzed: sā api na sambhavati
translated: That also is not possible.

analyzed: kāraṇa abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no cause.

analyzed: śarīre sati tad āśraya indriya sadbhāvaḥ
translated: When there is a body, there is the presence of the senses that depend on it.

analyzed: taiḥ artha ālocanam
translated: By them, there is the apprehension of objects.

analyzed: tatas pūrva anubhūta sārūpyeṇa iṣya aniṣya sādhana tva anumānam
translated: Then, by similarity to what was experienced before, there is the inference of being the means of attaining the desirable and undesirable.

analyzed: tasmāt icchā dveṣau
translated: From that, there is desire and aversion.

analyzed: tābhyām prayatnaḥ
translated: From those, there is effort.

analyzed: tatas ca iṣya sādhana upādānam
translated: And then, there is the acquisition of the means of attaining the desirable.

analyzed: aniṣya sādhana hānam ca
translated: And the avoidance of the means of attaining the undesirable.

analyzed: tatas sukha utpādaḥ
translated: Then, there is the production of pleasure.

analyzed: tad anantaram tad pratītiḥ iti eva dṛṣṭa kāraṇa kramaḥ
translated: This is the seen sequence of causes: the cognition of that [pleasure] immediately after that.

analyzed: adṛṣṭam ca sarvatra vijayate
translated: And the unseen [cause] triumphs everywhere.

analyzed: na ca eṣa kāraṇa pravāhaḥ muktau asti
translated: And this stream of causes does not exist in liberation.

analyzed: tad sadbhāve duḥkhasya api prasaṅgena mukta tva vyāghātāt
translated: Because if that [pleasure] existed, there would be a contradiction in being liberated by implication even from suffering.

analyzed: tasmāt sukha rahitaḥ eva mokṣaḥ
translated: Therefore, liberation is indeed devoid of pleasure.

original: kathamayaṃ puruṣārtha iti cet śarīraṃ ṣaḍindriyāṇi ṣaḍviṣayāḥ ṣaḍbuddhayaḥ sukhaṃ duḥkhaṃ cetyekaviṃśatibhedaduḥkhātyantanivṛttitvāditi brūmaḥ
analyzed: katham ayam puruṣa arthaḥ iti ced śarīram ṣaḍ indriyāṇi ṣaṭ viṣayāḥ ṣaṣ buddhayaḥ sukham duḥkham ca iti ekaviṃśati bheda duḥkha atyanta nivṛtti tvāt iti brūmaḥ
translated: If it is asked how this is the human goal, we say it is because of the complete cessation of suffering, which is divided into twenty-one parts: the body, the six sense faculties, the six sense objects, the six cognitions, pleasure, and pain.

analyzed: duḥkha nivṛttiḥ puruṣa arthaḥ eva na bhavati
translated: The cessation of suffering is not itself the human goal.
Because its being the human goal is qualified.

original: sukhaṃ duḥkhābhāve satyeva bhavatīti sukhārthaṃ duḥkhābhāvo mṛgyate na tu sa eva puruṣasya samīhita iti cet na /
analyzed: sukham duḥkha abhāve sati eva bhavati iti sukha artham duḥkha abhāvaḥ mṛgyate na tu saḥ eva puruṣasya samīhitaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is said that pleasure occurs only when there is the absence of suffering, so the absence of suffering is sought for the sake of pleasure, but that alone is not desired by the person, it is not so.

analyzed: viparyayasya api sadbhāvāt
translated: Because the opposite is also possible.

original: bhojanādisukhe satyeva bubhukṣādiduḥkhaṃ nivartata iti duḥkhanivṛttyarthameva bhojanādisukhaṃ mṛgyate na punastadeva puruṣasya samīhitamiti
analyzed: bhojana ādi sukhe sati eva bubhukṣā ādi duḥkham nivartate iti duḥkha nivṛtti artham eva bhojana ādi sukham mṛgyate na punar tat eva puruṣasya samīhitam iti
translated: When there is pleasure in eating and so on, the suffering of hunger and so on ceases. So the pleasure of eating and so on is sought only for the sake of the cessation of suffering, and it is not again considered to be what is desired by the person.

analyzed: kalpyate
translated: It is imagined.

analyzed: kvacid duḥkha nivṛtti abhāve pi sukhasya iṣyamāṇa tvāt iti ced na
translated: If it is said that pleasure is sometimes desired even in the absence of the cessation of suffering, it is not so.

original: duḥkhanivṛttirapi kvacitsukhābhāve 'pīṣyamāṇatvāt /🔽duḥkhanivṛttau satyāṃ sukhameva bhaviṣyatītyabhisandhistāvadastīti cet /
analyzed: duḥkha nivṛttiḥ api kvacid sukha abhāve pīṣyamāṇa tvāt  duḥkha nivṛttau satyām sukham eva bhaviṣyati iti abhisandhiḥ tāvat asti iti ced
translated: And the cessation of pain is also desired in some cases even when there is no pleasure.🔽If it is argued that there is the intention that when there is cessation of pain, there will surely be pleasure,

analyzed: sukha avasthāyām niyataḥ duḥkha virahaḥ bhavati iti abhisandheḥ tatra api sadbhāvāt
translated: then, because there is the intention that in the state of pleasure there is a definite absence of pain, it exists there also.

original: tasmādyadyapi duḥkhābhāve sukhaṃ sukhe ca duḥkhābhāvo niyataḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt yadi api duḥkha abhāve sukham sukhe ca duḥkha abhāvaḥ niyataḥ
translated: Therefore, although in the absence of pain there is pleasure, and in pleasure there is a definite absence of pain,

analyzed: tathā api parasparam nirapekṣam eva puruṣa artha tvam anayoḥ
translated: nevertheless, these two have mutual independence in being the human goal.

analyzed: icchāyāḥ
translated: Because desire has an unrelated object.

analyzed: bhavati duḥkha hāniḥ puruṣa arthaḥ kim tu anubhūyamāna tayā
translated: The cessation of pain is a human goal, but only when it is experienced.

original: nahi viṣādijanyamohāvasthāyāṃ duḥkhanivṛttiriti tatra prekṣāvantaḥ pravartante /

translated: For when one is in a state of delusion caused by poison etc., the cessation of pain is not experienced, and therefore the wise do not engage in it.

analyzed: tasmāt mokṣe duḥkha hāneḥ ananubhūyamāna tvāt na puruṣa artha tvam iti ced na
translated: Therefore, if the cessation of pain in liberation is not experienced, it is not a human goal. This is not so.

analyzed: putra ādi viyoga janya duḥkha hānim icchatām keṣāñcid viṣa śastra udbandhana ādau api pravṛtti darśanāt
translated: Because some who desire the cessation of pain caused by separation from a son etc. are seen to engage in things like poison, weapons, and hanging.

analyzed: prekṣāvantaḥ na evam kurvanti iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the wise do not act in this way, this is not so.

analyzed: puruṣa artha tva avirodhāt
translated: Because there is no contradiction with being a human goal.

original: nahi paradāreṣu śāstraniṣedhāṅkuśavāritaḥ prekṣāvanto nābhivartanta iti na tatra kāmaḥ puruṣārthaḥ /
analyzed: nahi para dāreṣu śāstra niṣedha aṅkuśa vāritaḥ prekṣāvantaḥ na abhivartante iti na tatra kāmaḥ puruṣa arthaḥ
translated: For the wise do not engage in sexual intercourse with another's wife, restrained by the goad of scriptural prohibition, so desire is not a human goal in that case.

original: api tvalpīyaḥ sukhaṃ mahīyānanartha iti nivṛttiḥ /

translated: Similarly, for one who has engaged in drinking alcohol and gambling, the small harm is averted and the great harm arises, so they do not engage in those.

analyzed: iyam eva hi prekṣā yat puruṣa arthe śāstra loka virodha parāmarśaḥ
translated: For this alone is wisdom: that even in the case of a human goal, one considers whether it is contradicted by scripture or worldly practice.

analyzed: sva rūpeṇa iṣyamāṇa tā mātra nibandhana tvāt puruṣa artha tāyāḥ
translated: Because being a human goal is based merely on being desired in its own form.

original: ata eva yatra lokaśāstrāvirodhastatra vyādhyādiparipīḍitāḥ prayagavāripātānaśanādināpi dehaṃ tyajantaḥ prekṣāvanto 'pi dṛśyante / /
analyzed: atas eva yatra loka śāstra avirodhaḥ tatra vyādhi ādi paripīḍitāḥ prayaga vāri pāta anaśana ādinā api deham tyajantaḥ prekṣāvantaḥ dṛśyante  /

analyzed: na kvacid duḥkha nivṛttim anubhaviṣyāmi iti tad sādhane pravartante

analyzed: api tu duḥkham hāsyāmi iti

analyzed: api ca duḥkha nivṛtteḥ anubhūyamāna tā mātram vivakṣitam
translated: Moreover, the mere experience of the cessation of suffering is intended.

analyzed: duḥkha nivṛtti sattā api vā
translated: Or the existence of the cessation of suffering.

analyzed: ādyeḥ ced tuṣyatu durjanaḥ carame janmani anubhūyate eva  samādhi bhāva avadhi
translated: If it is the first, let the wicked be satisfied. It is experienced in the last birth.

analyzed: dātyantikī duḥkha nivṛttiḥ api anāgatā āvartamānā api aciram anubhūyate eva
translated: The cessation of suffering is absolutely final, even if it does not exist in the future or present, it is experienced for a short time.

analyzed: dvitīye tu prasakta kaṇṭaka ādi hetuka duḥkha nivṛtteḥ apuruṣa artha tva prasaṅgaḥ
translated: But in the second case, the cessation of suffering caused by thorns etc. that are connected would be purposeless,

analyzed: sarvadā an anubhūyamāna tvāt

analyzed: tathātve vā viṣaya antara sañcāra abhāva prasaṅgaḥ
translated: If it were so, there would be the undesirable consequence of the absence of movement to other objects,

analyzed: nivṛtteḥ sarvadā tādavasthyāt
translated: because the cessation would always remain the same.

analyzed: tasmāt sukha rahitaḥ mokṣaḥ puruṣa arthaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, liberation, which is devoid of pleasure, is the human goal.

analyzed: nirākaroti na etat iti
translated: He refutes this with This is not so.

analyzed: na etat api atra śobhanam
translated: This view that it is devoid of pleasure is also not proper here.

analyzed: atra muktau
translated: Here, in liberation.

analyzed: etat sukha rāhitya matam api na śobhanam
translated: This view that it is devoid of pleasure is also not proper.

analyzed: kutas iti atas āha śrūyate iti
translated: Why? To this he says It is heard.

analyzed: śrutayaḥ yatas
translated: Because of the scriptures.

original: mahānandaṃ ca bhogaṃ ca niyamena vadanti hi // / /d //
analyzed: mahā ānandam ca bhogam ca niyamena vadanti hi
translated: They invariably speak of great bliss and enjoyment.

analyzed: atra iti vartate
translated: Here, the word here is used.

analyzed: bhogam tad anubhavam
translated: Enjoyment is the experience of that.

analyzed: niyamena avigānena

analyzed: iti śrutīnām prasiddha tām ācaṣṭe

analyzed: tāḥ ca udāhariṣyante  nanu aśarīram vāva santam na priya apriye spṛśate
translated: And they will be quoted.

analyzed: iti muktasya duḥkha vat sukhasya api hāniḥ śrūyate  tathā na pretya saṃjñā asti
translated: But it is heard that even for the liberated one, there is the loss of happiness like sorrow, as stated in the Upanishad: When one is truly bodiless, neither pleasure nor pain touches him.

analyzed: iti jñāna abhāvāt ca

translated: So how is this? Therefore, he explains the statement about not being touched by pleasure, saying natural and so on.

translated: The loss of natural pleasure is called not being touched by pleasure.

translated: Suspecting the loss of knowledge of this, Maitreyī said to me, You are deluded.

original: bhavānityuktavatyā hi nāhaṃ mohaṃ vadāmi te /
analyzed: bhavān iti uktavatyā hi na aham moham vadāmi te
translated: For she who said, I do not speak of delusion to you,

analyzed: iti uktavā yājñavalkyaḥ hi sva rūpa anāśam ūcivān
translated: Having said this, Yājñavalkya indeed spoke of the non-destruction of the nature.

original: vijñānaghana evaitebhyo bhūtebhyaḥ samutthāya tānyevānuvinaśyati na pretya saṃjñāsti' /
analyzed: vijñāna ghanaḥ eva etebhyaḥ bhūtebhyaḥ samutthāya tāni eva anuvinaśyati na pretya saṃjñā asti
translated: This Self, which is a mass of knowledge, having risen from these elements, is destroyed along with them. After death, there is no consciousness.

analyzed: vijñāna mūrtiḥ ayam ātmā anādiḥ api carame janmani etebhyaḥ bhūtebhyaḥ samutthāya bhūta ātmaka śarīra utpatti nimittam eva utpanna vyavahāra viṣaye
translated: This Self, which is of the nature of knowledge, although beginningless, having risen from these elements in the final birth, for the sake of the production of the body consisting of the elements,

original: bhūtvā punastāni bhūtānyanveva tannāśanimittameva nityo 'pi vinaśyati / /
analyzed: bhūtvā punar tāni bhūtāni anu eva tad nāśa nimittam eva vinaśyati
translated: having become so, is destroyed along with those elements, for the sake of their destruction alone, although eternal.

analyzed: vinaṣṭa vyavahāra gocaraḥ
translated: Having become one whose sphere of activity is destroyed,

analyzed: viṣayaḥ bhavati
translated: becomes an object.

original: apavrajyata iti yāvat /🔽tataḥ pretya mokṣānantaramasya muktasya saṃjñā jñānaṃ nāstītyaviśadaṃ yājñavalkyavākyaṃ
analyzed: apavrajyate iti yāvat  tatas pretya mokṣa anantaram asya muktasya saṃjñā jñānam na asti iti aviśadam yājñavalkya vākyam
translated: Up to the point of renouncing the world.🔽Having heard this unclear statement of Yajnavalkya that after death, after liberation, there is no consciousness or knowledge for this liberated one,

original: śrutvā asya muktasya jñānahānimāśaṅkayānena vākyena mukto na jānātītyucyata iti matvā
analyzed: śrutvā asya muktasya jñāna hānim āśaṅkaya anena vākyena muktaḥ na jānāti iti ucyate iti matvā
translated: thinking that this statement expresses the doubt that there is loss of knowledge for this liberated one,

original: maitreyyāatraiva mā bhavānmohāntamāpipat' /🔽iti vākye bhavānmāṃ prati yadāha mukto na jānātīti tanmohakamevetyarthamuktavatyā codita iti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: maitreyyā atrā eva mā bhavān moha antam āpipat  iti vākye bhavān mām prati yat āha muktaḥ na jānāti iti tat mohakam eva iti artham uktavatyā coditaḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Maitreyi says here: Do not fall into delusion, O Sir.🔽The meaning is that what you say to me, O Sir, that the liberated one does not know, is delusion only. The rest is understood.

original: yājñavalkyo na vā are 'haṃ mohaṃ bravīmītyanena jñānopadeśāya pravṛtto 'haṃ paramapriyāyai
analyzed: yājñavalkyaḥ na vai are ham moham bravīmi iti anena jñāna upadeśāya pravṛttaḥ ham parama priyāyai
translated: Yajnavalkya, with the statement I do not speak of delusion, O dear one, having made the promise that I do not speak of delusion to you who are most dear,

original: te mohaṃ na vadāmīti pratijñāmuktvā kathamityāśaṅkāyāmavināśī vā are 'yamātmetyātmasvarūpasyānāśamūcivān /
analyzed: te moham na vadāmi iti pratijñām uktvā katham iti āśaṅkāyām avināśī vai are yam ātmā iti ātma svarūpasya anāśam ūcivān
translated: when the doubt arises how is it so?, he has said that the nature of the Self is indestructible, with the words This Self, O dear one, is indestructible.

analyzed: yat vā āśaṅkayā iti ṇic antāt layap
translated: Or, the suffix lya is used from the root to doubt with the ṇijanta affix.

analyzed: yājñavalkyaḥ saṃmugdhena vacasā asyāḥ maitreyyāḥ jñāna hānim āśaṅkayā ūcivān iti yojanā
translated: The construction is: Yajnavalkya, suspecting loss of knowledge in this Maitreyi due to confused speech, said.

original: tasyāstathā śaṅkā jātetyatra kiṃ mānamityatroktaṃ mohamāha māṃ bhavānityuktavatyā hīti vacanaliṅgenāśaṅkāva🔽gamyata ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: tasyāḥ tathā śaṅkā jātā iti atra kim mānam iti atra uktam moham āha mām bhavān iti uktavatyā hi iti vacana liṅgena āśaṅkā avasthā  gamyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the doubt is understood from the gender of the sentence.

original: ayamarthaḥ spaṣṭa eva śrutāviti dvitīyo hiśabdaḥ / /
analyzed: ayam arthaḥ spaṣṭaḥ eva śrutau iti dvitīyaḥ hi śabdaḥ
translated: The meaning is clear in the scripture itself. This is the second hi word.

original: jñānavināśavacanaṃ mohakamityākṣepe svarūpānāśo 'saṅgataḥ kathamukta ityata āha jñānasvarūpasyeti //
analyzed: jñāna vināśa vacanam mohakam iti ākṣepe svarūpa anāśaḥ saṅgataḥ katham uktaḥ iti atas āha jñāna svarūpasya iti
translated: In the objection that the statement of the destruction of knowledge is deceptive, it is said that the non-destruction of the nature is irrelevant. How was it said? To this he says of the nature of knowledge, etc.

analyzed: jñāna rūpasya vijñāna anāśaḥ tad nāśaḥ eva yat
translated: The non-destruction of consciousness, which is of the nature of knowledge, is the destruction of that.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus...

original: yat yasmājjñānarūpastāvadātmā tasya ca vijñānanāśo nāma tannāśa eva /
analyzed: yat yasmāt jñāna rūpaḥ tāvat ātmā tasya ca vijñāna nāśaḥ nāma tad nāśaḥ eva
translated: Because of that, the self is of the nature of knowledge. And the destruction of consciousness is the destruction of that.

analyzed: na ca ātma nāśaḥ sti
translated: And there is no destruction of the self.

analyzed: tathā sati mukteḥ apuruṣa artha tva prasaṅgāt
translated: If it were so, then liberation would follow as not being a human goal.

analyzed: atas na jñāna nāśaḥ sti
translated: Therefore, there is no destruction of knowledge.

original: ata eva na madvacanaṃ tadartham /🔽kiṃ tvamuktānāṃ muktaviṣaye saṃjñā nāsti /
analyzed: atas eva na mad vacanam tad artham  kim tu a muktānām mukta viṣaye saṃjñā na asti
translated: For this very reason, my statement is not for that purpose.

original: muktānāmeva vā vṛttirūpā saṃjñā nāstītyādireva madvacanārtha ityabhiprāyavānsvarūpānāśamūcivāniti sambandhaḥ / /
analyzed: muktānām eva vā vṛtti rūpā saṃjñā na asti ityādiḥ eva mad vacana arthaḥ iti abhiprāyavān svarūpa ānāśam ūcivān iti sambandhaḥ
translated: Rather, the meaning of my statement is that there is no consciousness of those who are liberated, or that there is no consciousness in the form of activity for the liberated ones themselves, and so on. This is the intended meaning. The connection is that he spoke of the non-destruction of the nature.

original: astvevaṃ saṅgatistathāpi jñānaṃ na naśyatīti sākṣādanuktvaivaṃ vacanaṃ kimarthamityata āha śūnyeti //
analyzed: astu evam saṅgatiḥ tathā api jñānam na naśyati iti sākṣāt an uktvā evam vacanam kimartham iti atas āha śūnya iti
translated: Even so, the connection is established. Still, why did he speak thus without directly stating that knowledge does not perish? To this he says śūnya etc.

analyzed: śūnya mata ucchittyai
translated: For the destruction of the doctrine of emptiness...

original: na kevalamatra prameyanirūpaṇamātrārthaṃ pravṛtto yājñavalkyaḥ kintu parīkṣāyāṃkṣayā /
analyzed: na kevalam atra prameya nirūpaṇa mātra artham pravṛttaḥ yājñavalkyaḥ kintu parīkṣā āyāṃkṣayā
translated: Yājñavalkya did not engage in this discussion merely to describe the object of knowledge, but rather to refute the doctrine of emptiness.

original: ata eva na pretya jñāyata iti viśadamanuktvā śaṅkotpādanāya na pretya saṃjñāstīti sādhāraṇaṃ vākyamāha /
analyzed: atas eva na pretya jñāyate iti viśadam an uktvā śaṅkā utpādanāya na pretya saṃjñā asti iti sādhāraṇam vākyam āha
translated: For this very reason, he did not clearly state it is not known after death, but spoke a general statement there is no consciousness after death to generate doubt.

analyzed: parīkṣā ca sva anabhimata nirāsa rūpā
translated: And examination is in the form of refuting what is not accepted by oneself.

original: ata evamuttare datte śūnyamatasyātmanāśalakṣaṇasya niraso 'pi kṛto bhavatīti tadarthaṃ svarūpānāśamūcivān /
analyzed: atas evam uttare datte śūnyamatasya ātma nāśa lakṣaṇasya nirasaḥ api kṛtaḥ bhavati iti tad artham svarūpa anāśam ūcivān
translated: For this very reason, when this is stated as the answer, the refutation of the doctrine of emptiness, which is characterized by the non-destruction of the self, is also accomplished. Therefore, for that purpose, he spoke of the non-destruction of the essential nature.

analyzed: yad artham āditas vākyam vyākhyātam tat idānīm anucchitti dharmā iti etat vayācaṣṭe punar iti  punar ānanda pūrvakān
translated: The purpose for which the sentence was explained at the beginning, that is now explained by anucchitti-dharme etc. He says punar etc.🔽Again, he speaks of the dharmas preceded by bliss.

analyzed: dharmān āha api anucchinnān
translated: Even though spoken of as not destroyed...

analyzed: sva rūpa anāśam uktvā punar api muktasya ānanda pūvarkān dharmān anucchinnān āha yājñavalkyaḥ
translated: Having spoken of the non-destruction of the essential nature, Yājñavalkya again speaks of the dharmas preceded by bliss as not destroyed for the liberated one.

original: svarūpānāśoktyaiva dharmānucchittisiddhau punaruktiriyamityata uktamānandapūrvakāniti /🔽vākyopakrame vijñānaghana eveti vijñānasyātmasvarūpatvamuktaṃ na punarānandapūrvakāniti /
analyzed: svarūpa anāśa uktyā eva dharma anucchitti siddhau punaruktiḥ iyam iti atas uktam ānanda pūrvakān iti  vākya upakrame vijñāna ghanaḥ eva iti vijñānasya ātma svarūpa tvam uktam na punar ānanda pūrvakān iti
translated: Since the non-destruction of the nature is stated, the non-cutting off of the attributes is established. This is stated again to show that the attributes are not cut off.🔽In the beginning of the sentence, it is said that Brahman is pure consciousness, so consciousness is the nature of the self, not that the attributes beginning with bliss are not.

original: vākyopakrame vijñānaghana eveti vijñānasyātmasvarūpatvamuktaṃ na punarānandapūrvakāṇām /
analyzed: vākya upakrame vijñāna ghanaḥ eva iti vijñānasya ātma svarūpa tvam uktam na punar ānanda pūrvakāṇām
translated: In the beginning of the sentence, it is said that Brahman is pure consciousness, so consciousness is the nature of the self, not that the attributes beginning with bliss are not.

original: ataḥ svarūpānāśoktyā vijñānāvināśa eva sujñāno nānandādyavināśaḥ /
analyzed: atas sva rūpa anāśa uktyā vijñāna avināśaḥ eva su jñānaḥ na ānanda ādi avināśaḥ
translated: Therefore, by stating the non-destruction of the nature, the non-destruction of consciousness is well known, not the non-destruction of bliss etc.

original: ataste 'pi vijñānavat ātmasvarūpabhūtā eva nocchidyante ityarthapratipattyarthamidaṃ vākyamiti / /🔽tātparyāntaraṃ sūcayati tārkikairiti /
analyzed: atas te pi vijñāna vat ātma svarūpa bhūtāḥ eva na ucchidyante iti artha pratipatti artham idam vākyam iti  tātparya antaram sūcayati tārkikaiḥ iti
translated: Hence, they also, like consciousness, are only the nature of the self and are not cut off. This sentence is for the purpose of understanding this meaning.🔽He indicates another purport with by the logicians.

analyzed: tārkikaiḥ vinivāritān
translated: Those that are refuted by the logicians...

analyzed: uktam etat parīkṣāyām pravṛttaḥ yājñavalkyaḥ iti
translated: This has been stated in the examination that Yajnavalkya is engaged.

original: ataḥ svarūpāvināśamaṅgīkṛtya ye tārkikā buddhisukhādīndharmānmuktasya vinivārayanti te 'pyasamīcīnavādina iti jñāpanāyedaṃ vākyamiti na paunaruktyadoṣaḥ
analyzed: atas svarūpa avināśam aṅgīkṛtya ye tārkikāḥ buddhi sukha ādīn dharmān muktasya vinivārayanti te pi asamīcīna vādinaḥ iti jñāpanāya idam vākyam iti na paunaruktya doṣaḥ
translated: Therefore, accepting the non-destruction of the nature, those logicians who refute the attributes like intellect, bliss etc. of the liberated one, they also are propounding an incorrect doctrine. This sentence is for the purpose of making this known. There is no fault of repetition.

analyzed: nanu svarūpa avināśa uktyā dharma avināśaḥ pi siddhaḥ eva
translated: But by the statement of the indestructibility of the nature, the indestructibility of the attributes is also established.

analyzed: satyam
translated: True.

analyzed: sva mata rītyā tat
translated: That is according to their own view.

analyzed: tārkikāḥ tu na jñāna sukha ādīnām ātma svarūpa tvam manyante
translated: But the logicians do not consider knowledge, pleasure, etc. to be the nature of the self.

analyzed: atas kim idānīm mokṣa prasaṅge teṣām ātma svarūpa tva upapādanena
translated: So what is the point of establishing their identity with the nature of the self in the context of liberation?

analyzed: ātma svarūpa prakriyāyām tat api vaktavyam iti āśayena anucchittiḥ evā uktā iti
translated: With the idea that it should be mentioned in the description of the nature of the self, the indestructibility alone is stated.

analyzed: idam atra ākūtam
translated: This is the intention here.

original: anucchittidharmeti yadi saṅkhayādidharmāṇāmanucchittiruktā syāt tadā asaṅgatamidaṃ vākyamāpadyeta /
analyzed: an ucchitti dharmā iti yadi saṅkhaya ādi dharmāṇām anucchittiḥ uktā syāt tadā asaṅgatam idam vākyam āpadyeta
translated: If the indestructibility of attributes like number, etc. were mentioned by this statement having the attribute of indestructibility, then this statement would become irrelevant.

analyzed: jñāna vināśa vacanam mohaḥ iti ākṣepe saṅkhaya ādya vināśa kathanasya saṅgati adarśanāt
translated: Because the statement of the indestructibility of number, etc. is not seen to be relevant in the objection the statement of the destruction of knowledge is delusion.

original: yadi ca svarūpāvināśo 'nenokta iti syāttadā tasya pūrvavākyenaivoktatvāt punaruktidoṣaḥ syāt /
analyzed: yadi ca svarūpa avināśaḥ nena uktaḥ iti syāt tadā tasya pūrva vākyena eva ukta tvāt punarukti doṣaḥ syāt
translated: And if it were said that the indestructibility of the nature is stated by this, then because it has already been stated by the previous statement, there would be the fault of repetition.

analyzed: asmad pakṣe tu asti sarveṣām vākyānām ukta rītyā sāphalyam
translated: But in our view, all the statements have purpose in the manner stated.

analyzed: tasmāt jñāna ānanda ādi guṇānām eva anucchittim āha idam vākyam iti gamyate
translated: Therefore, it is understood that this statement speaks of the indestructibility of the qualities like knowledge, bliss, etc.

original: tadbalācca na pretya saṃjñāstītyetadapi uktārthameveti / /🔽itaścaitaduktātharmevetyāha mātreti //
analyzed: tad balāt ca na pretya saṃjñā asti iti etat api ukta artham eva iti  itas ca etat ukta atharma eva iti āha mātrā iti
translated: And from that strength, it is said that there is no consciousness after death. This also has the same meaning as the stated meaning.

analyzed: mātrā saṃsargam api āha tathā
translated: And for this reason also, this has the same stated meaning, he says 'mātrā' etc.🔽He also says the contact with the object, thus...

original: yathā dharmānucchittimāha tathā mīyanta iti mātrā rūpādayo viṣayāsteṣāṃ saṃsargamupabhogalakṣaṇamapyasyāhamātrāsaṃsargastvasya bhavati' /
analyzed: yathā dharma anucchittim āha tathā mīyante iti mātrāḥ rūpa ādayaḥ viṣayāḥ teṣām saṃsargam upabhoga lakṣaṇam api asya aha mātrā saṃsargaḥ tu asya bhavati
translated: As he says for the non-destruction of dharma, thus they are measured, the objects like form are the mātrās, their contact characterized by enjoyment also he says 'mātrāsaṃsargaḥ' is his.

analyzed: iti vākyena
translated: By this sentence.

analyzed: tatas na jñāna vilopaḥ vyākhyātum śakyate
translated: Therefore, the destruction of knowledge cannot be explained.

original: nedaṃ vākyaṃ śrutāvupalabhyata ityata uktam mādhyandinaśrutiriti //
analyzed: na idam vākyam śrutau upalabhyate iti atas uktam mādhyandina śrutiḥ iti
translated: Since this sentence is not found in the scripture, it is said 'the Mādhyandina scripture'.

analyzed: mādhyandina śrutiḥ
translated: The Mādhyandina scripture...

original: maitreyīyājñavalkyasaṃvādarūpamidaṃ prakaraṇaṃ kāṇvamādhyandinaśrutyoḥ samānam /🔽idaṃ tu vākyaṃ yadyapi kāṇvaśrutau nāsti tathāpi mādhyandinaśrutāvastyeveti / /
analyzed: maitreyī yājñavalkya saṃvāda rūpam idam prakaraṇam kāṇva mādhyandina śrutyoḥ samānam  idam tu vākyam yadi api kāṇva śrutau na asti tathā api mādhyandina śrutau asti eva iti
translated: This section in the form of the dialogue between Maitreyī and Yājñavalkya is common to the Kāṇva and Mādhyandina recensions.🔽But this sentence, although not found in the Kāṇva recension, does exist in the Mādhyandina recension.

analyzed: saṃjñā na asti iti vākyam ukta artham eva iti āha ācikṣepa iti
translated: From this also, the sentence 'there is no consciousness' has the same stated meaning, he says 'ācikṣepa' etc.

original: ācikṣepa mataṃ tacca yasmin na viṣayādanam // / / //
analyzed: ācikṣepa matam tat ca yasmin na viṣaya adanam
translated: And that view which he declared, in which there is no eating of objects...🔽...

analyzed: śrutiḥ iti vakṣyati
translated: The Śruti will say.

analyzed: yatra hi dvaitam iva bhavati
translated: Where there is duality as it were,

original: ityādiruttarā śrutiryasminmate muktasya na viṣayādanaṃ rūpādiviṣayabhogo nāstītyabhyupagamastanmatamācikṣepa ninditavatīti /
analyzed: ityādiḥ uttarā śrutiḥ yasmin mate muktasya na viṣaya adanam rūpa ādi viṣaya bhogaḥ na asti iti abhyupagamaḥ tat matam ācikṣepa ninditavatī iti
translated: This is the later Śruti which censures the view that in the liberated state there is no enjoyment of objects like form.

original: tataśca na tadvākyaṃ muktasya jñānābhāvaṃ pratipādayati /
analyzed: tatas ca na tat vākyam muktasya jñāna abhāvam pratipādayati
translated: And therefore that passage does not teach the absence of knowledge in the liberated one.

original: nahi jñānarahitasya ghaṭakalpasya viṣayasaṃsargo vā tadabhāvanindā vopapadyate /
analyzed: nahi jñāna rahitasya ghaṭa kalpasya viṣaya saṃsargaḥ vā tad abhāva nindā vā upapadyate
translated: For it is not proper for a pot-like being devoid of knowledge to have contact with objects or for that absence to be censured.

analyzed: katham ācikṣepa iti ced
translated: If it is asked how it censures,

analyzed: ucyate
translated: it is said:

original: yatra yadi / dvaitaṃ bhavati tat tarhyeva /🔽itara itaraṃ paśyatītyādinā vyāptimabhidhāya hiśabdena tasyāḥ pramitatvaṃ coktvā yatra yadi / tu /
analyzed: yatra yadi dvaitam bhavati tat tarhi eva  itaraḥ itaram paśyati ityādinā vyāptim abhidhāya hi śabdena tasyāḥ pramita tvam ca uktvā yatra yadi tu
translated: If there is duality anywhere, then at that time

analyzed: asya ātmanaḥ upekṣitam sarvam ātmā eva abhūt sva vyatiriktam na syāt
translated: by stating the pervasion with the other sees the other etc. and by stating the proof of that with the word since, it is said that if this Self were all that is desired and nothing else existed apart from itself,

original: tat tarhi kena sādhanena kam arthaṃ paśyeta /
analyzed: tat tarhi kena sādhanena kam artham paśyeta
translated: then by what means and for what purpose would it see?

analyzed: na kena api kiñcid iti aniṣya prasaṅgaḥ abhidhīyate
translated: By none at all, by anything at all - this undesirable consequence is stated.

original: evaṃ tarhi yadi muktau dvaitaṃ na syāttadā rūpadarśanādikaṃ na bhavediti tarkitaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: evam tarhi yadi muktau dvaitam na syāt tadā rūpa darśana ādikam na bhavet iti tarkitam bhavati
translated: If so, then it is inferred that if there were no duality in liberation, then seeing forms and so on would not occur.

analyzed: tathā ca dvaita abhāva matam anayā ākṣiptam  na viṣaya bhoga abhāva matam iti atas āha ghrāṇa ādi iti
translated: And thus the view of the non-existence of duality is refuted by this [scripture].

analyzed: ghrāṇa ādi bhoga abhāvasya tu aniṣṭa tva hṛdā śrutiḥ
translated: But the view of the non-existence of the enjoyment of objects is not [refuted]. Therefore it is said: The scripture intends that the non-existence of the enjoyment of smell and so on is undesirable.

analyzed: ghrāṇa ādinā gandha ādeḥ bhogaḥ ghrāṇa ādi bhogaḥ
translated: The enjoyment of smell and so on by means of the nose and so on is the enjoyment of smell and so on by the nose and so on.

analyzed: kena kam iti karaṇasya karmaṇaḥ ca ukta tvāt
translated: Since the instrument and the object have already been mentioned.

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ viśeṣa arthaḥ
translated: The word but has the meaning of distinction.

analyzed: hṛdā abhiprāyeṇa
translated: With the intention of the heart.

analyzed: pūrveṇa eva sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is with the previous [statement].

original: satyametat śūnyamataṃ tārkikamataṃ ca nirākṛtyādvaitamanayā śrutyā nirākriyata iti /
analyzed: satyam etat śūnya matam tārkika matam ca nirākṛtya advaitam anayā śrutyā nirākriyate iti
translated: This is true. After refuting the doctrine of emptiness and the doctrine of the logicians, the non-dual doctrine is refuted by this scripture.

analyzed: tat ca viṣaya bhoga abhāva prasañjanena
translated: And that [non-dual doctrine] is implied by the implication of the non-existence of the enjoyment of objects.

analyzed: prasañjanīyam ca tat bhavati yat aniṣyam
translated: And that which is undesirable is what is to be implied.

analyzed: atas dvaita mate ghrāṇa ādi bhoga abhāvam prasañjayantī śrutiḥ tasya aniṣṭa tvam abhipraiti iti gamyate
translated: Therefore, the scripture, implying the non-existence of the enjoyment of smell and so on in the non-dual doctrine, is understood to intend that it is undesirable.

original: aniṣyaṃ ca taducyate yadaprāmāṇikaṃ pramāṇaviruddhaṃ ca /
analyzed: aniṣyam ca tat ucyate yat aprāmāṇikam pramāṇa viruddham ca
translated: And that which is undesirable is said to be that which is not authoritative and contradicts the means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: atas viṣaya bhoga abhāva nindā śruti abhiprāya vyāptā bhavati eva iti
translated: Therefore, the censure of the absence of enjoyment of objects is indeed pervaded by the intention of the Vedas.

original: bhavedevamarthāpattyā viṣayabhogābhāvanindāvagamo yadyatrādvaitamate viṣayabhogābhāvaḥ prasañjanīyaḥ syāt /
analyzed: bhavet evam arthāpattyā viṣaya bhoga abhāva nindā avagamaḥ yadi atra advaita mate viṣaya bhoga abhāvaḥ prasañjanīyaḥ syāt
translated: This would be so, the understanding of the censure of the absence of enjoyment of objects through presumption, if the absence of enjoyment of objects were to be raised as a consequence in this non-dualistic view.

analyzed: na ca evam
translated: But this is not so.

analyzed: api tarhi vastu sthiti kathanam etat
translated: Rather, this is a statement of the way things are.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: To explain:

analyzed: ayam ātmā avināśī atas eva an ucchittiḥ tasya dharmaḥ
translated: This Self is imperishable. For this very reason, its attribute is non-destruction.

analyzed: muktau mātrābhiḥ a saṃsargaḥ tasya bhavati
translated: In liberation, it has no contact with the limiting adjuncts.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why is that?

original: yatra hi saṃsāre dvaitamiva bhavati tattatretara itaraṃ paśyatītyādi /
analyzed: yatra hi saṃsāre dvaitam iva bhavati tat tatra itaraḥ itaram paśyati ityādi
translated: For where in the world duality seems to exist, there one sees the other, etc.

original: yatra tu muktāvasya sarvamātmaivābhūtsvavyatiriktaṃ kimapi nāsti tatra kena kaṃ paśyenna kenāpi na kimapītyadvaitinaḥ /
analyzed: yatra tu muktau asya sarvam ātmā eva abhūt sva vyatiriktam kim api nā asti tatra kena kam paśyet na kena api na kim api iti advaitinaḥ
translated: But when in liberation everything has become the Self itself and nothing exists apart from itself, then by whom and whom does one see? By no one and nothing, say the non-dualists.

original: tatrāha yeneti //🔽yenedamakhilaṃ veda vijñātāraṃ svameva ca /
analyzed: tatra āha yena iti  yena idam akhilam veda vijñātāram svam eva ca
translated: There it is said: By whom🔽By whom this entire universe is known, and also the knower itself,

original: kena taṃ ca vijānīyādityaniṣṭaṃ hi sarvathā // / / //
analyzed: kena tam ca vijānīyāt iti aniṣṭam hi sarvathā
translated: By whom that [Self] should be known - this is indeed undesirable in every way.

original: yenedamakhilaṃ veda taṃ ca kena vijānīyāt vijñātāraṃ ca kena vijānīyādityanena yenedaṃ sarvaṃ vijānāti taṃ ca kena vijānīyāt vijñātāramare 🔽kena vijānīyāditi vākyadvayamupādatte /
analyzed: yena idam akhilam veda tam ca kena vijānīyāt vijñātāram ca kena vijānīyāt iti anena yena idam sarvam vijānāti tam ca kena vijānīyāt vijñātāram are  kena vijānīyāt iti vākya dvayam upādatte
translated: By what could one know him by whom this entire world is known, and by what could one know the knower? By this, he quotes two sentences: By what could one know him by whom this entire world is known, and by what could one know the knower?🔽He quotes the two sentences By what could one know him and By what could one know the knower.

analyzed: vijñātāram iti etat svam eva iti vyācaṣṭe
translated: He explains the knower as himself.

analyzed: prathama vākya viṣayam sūtrasya vakṣyati
translated: He will say that the sutra is about the first sentence.

analyzed: iti vākya dvaya uktam viṣṇu jñāna rāhityam sva jñāna rāhityam ca
translated: The absence of knowledge of Vishnu and the absence of self-knowledge stated by these two sentences,

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: this is what is said.

analyzed: atra ante yena idam iti vākya dvayam śrūyate
translated: Here at the end, the two sentences By whom this are heard.

original: tadarthaḥ parameśvarajñānābhāvaḥ svajñānābhāvaśca tāvadaniṣyo na vāstavaḥ /
analyzed: tad arthaḥ parameśvara jñāna abhāvaḥ sva jñāna abhāvaḥ ca tāvat aniṣyaḥ na vāstavaḥ
translated: The meaning of that, the absence of knowledge of the Supreme Lord and the absence of self-knowledge, is not undesirable and not real.

analyzed: tatas tad prasaṅga kathanam evā iti jñāyate
translated: Therefore, it is understood that it is merely a statement of the possibility arising from that.

original: tatsāhacaryātkena kaṃ paśyedityādikamapi prasañjanameva na vastusthitikathanamiti jñātavyamiti / /
analyzed: tad sāhacaryāt kena kam paśyet iti ādikam api prasañjanam eva na vastu sthiti kathanam iti jñātavyam iti
translated: From its association with that, it should be understood that even the statement beginning with By what could one see whom? is merely a statement of possibility, not a statement of the actual state of things.

analyzed: nanu īśvaraḥ tāvat sarvathā api aviśeṣaḥ eva
translated: But the Lord is indeed absolutely without any distinction,

analyzed: yatas vācaḥ ityādi śruteḥ
translated: because of the Vedic text beginning with From whom.

analyzed: jīva ātmā ca na sva vijñānī
translated: And the individual soul does not know itself.

analyzed: ekasyām kriyāyām ekasya eva kartṛ karma bhāvasya viruddha tvāt
translated: Because in one action, the state of being both agent and object of one [entity] is contradictory.

original: ataḥ parameśvarajñānābhāvaḥ svajñānābhāvaśca kathamaniṣya ityataḥ parameśvarasya savarthāpyavijñeyatvaṃ tāvannirākaroti neti //
analyzed: atas parameśvara jñāna abhāvaḥ sva jñāna abhāvaḥ ca katham aniṣyaḥ iti atas parameśvarasya tāvat nirākaroti na iti
translated: Therefore, how can the absence of knowledge of the Supreme Lord and the absence of one's own knowledge be undesirable? Hence, he first refutes the idea that the Supreme Lord is absolutely unknowable, saying No.

analyzed: na akhila jñāpakaḥ viṣṇuḥ ajñeyaḥ niyamena hi
translated: For, Viṣṇu, the knower of all, is not necessarily unknowable.

original: atrākhilajñāpaka ityanena yenedamiti vākyārthamanūdya viṣṇuriti tasya viṣayo darśitaḥ /
analyzed: atra akhila jñāpakaḥ iti anena yena idam iti vākya artham anūdya viṣṇuḥ iti tasya viṣayaḥ darśitaḥ
translated: Here, by the knower of all, the meaning of the sentence by whom this... is referred to, and by Viṣṇu, its object is shown.

analyzed: prāk a vyākhyāta tvāt
translated: Because it has not been explained before.

analyzed: viṣṇum vinā etad vākya atharsya asambhavāt
translated: Because the meaning of this sentence is not possible without Viṣṇu.

analyzed: hi śabdaḥ tāvat arthe
translated: The word for has the meaning of indeed.

analyzed: viṣṇuḥ niyamena sarvathā api ajñeyaḥ iti tāvat na bhavati
translated: Viṣṇu is not necessarily unknowable in every way.

analyzed: kutas iti atas āha tat iti
translated: Why is it so? Therefore, he says that.

analyzed: tad jñāna artham hi vedānām akhilānām pravartanam
translated: For, the purpose of all the Vedas is to bring about knowledge of that.

analyzed: sarve vedāḥ ityādeḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is because of such statements as 'all the Vedas.'

original: viṣṇoḥ sarvathāpyajñeyatve 'khilavedavaiyarthyaprasaṅgādyato vāca ityādikamanyathā vyākhyeyamiti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: viṣṇoḥ sarvathā api ajñeya tve khila veda vaiyarthya prasaṅgāt yatas vācaḥ ityādikam anyathā vyākhyeyam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that if Viṣṇu were unknowable in every way, it would follow that all the Vedas are useless, and therefore such statements as from which... must be explained in another way.

original: evaṃ paramātmano jñeyatvamupapādya jīvātmanaḥ svajñānamupapādayati pratyakṣamiti //
analyzed: evam paramātmanaḥ jñeya tvam upapādya jīvātmanaḥ sva jñānam upapādayati pratyakṣam iti
translated: Having thus established the knowability of the supreme self, he establishes the self-knowledge of the individual self with the words direct perception and so on.

analyzed: pratyakṣa āgama ātma vijñāna avirodha anubhavāt api
translated: Also because of the experience of non-contradiction with the knowledge of the self through direct perception and scripture,

analyzed: na sva vijñāni tāyām ca virodhaḥ kaścana iyate
translated: there is no contradiction whatsoever in the self-knowledge of the individual self.

analyzed: kriyā viśeṣaṇam etat  ātma vijñānam ca avirodhaḥ ca iti dvandvaḥ
translated: This is a qualification of the verb.🔽Knowledge of the self and non-contradiction form a copulative compound.

analyzed: avirodhaḥ ca prasaṅgāt ātmā vijñānaḥ eva
translated: And non-contradiction is, by implication, included in the knowledge of the self.

analyzed: tayoḥ anubhavaḥ
translated: The experience of those two.

analyzed: sa ca pratyakṣa rūpaḥ tasmāt
translated: And that is in the form of direct perception, from that.

analyzed: api padena śruti ādi grahaṇam
translated: By the word also, scripture and so on are included.

analyzed: sva vijñāni tāyām jīvasya kaścana virodhaḥ na iyate
translated: No contradiction whatsoever is seen in the self-knowledge of the individual self.

analyzed: na kā api anupapattiḥ pratīyate
translated: No inconsistency is perceived.

original: ātmavijñānānubhavastāvat māmahaṃ jānāmīti sākṣirūpaḥ prasiddha eva /
analyzed: ātma vijñāna anubhavaḥ tāvat mām aham jānāmi iti sākṣi rūpaḥ prasiddhaḥ eva
translated: The experience of the knowledge of the self is well-known in the form of the witness-consciousness I know myself.

original: yathā ghaṭamahaṃ jānāmītyatra na kācidanupapattiḥ pratīyate /
analyzed: yathā ghaṭam aham jānāmi iti atra na kācid anupapattiḥ pratīyate
translated: Just as in the case of I know the pot, no inconsistency is perceived.

analyzed: kim tu anupalambha sanāthena sākṣiṇā anupapatti abhāvaḥ eva sākṣātkriyate
translated: Rather, the absence of inconsistency is directly experienced by the witness, supported by non-apprehension.

analyzed: tathā tad a viśiṣye mām aham jānāmi iti jñāne pi
translated: Similarly, in the case of the knowledge I know myself, which is not different from that.

original: śrutayo 'piahamityeva yo vedyaḥ' / ityādyāḥ /🔽yadi cātmā na svātmānaṃ jānīyāttadā mamedamiṣyasādhanamityādijñānābhāvāttathāvidhecchāprayatnayorapyabhāvātsarvapravṛttinivṛttivilopaprasaṅgaḥ
analyzed: śrutayaḥ pi aham iti eva yaḥ vedyaḥ ityādyāḥ  yadi ca ātmā na sva ātmānam jānīyāt tadā mama idam iṣya sādhanam ityādi jñāna abhāvāt tathāvidha icchā prayatnayoḥ api abhāvāt sarva pravṛtti nivṛtti vilopa prasaṅgaḥ
translated: The Vedic texts also are: 'He who is to be known as I alone' (Tai. 2.1).🔽If the self did not know itself, then due to the absence of the knowledge 'this is the means to attain that', etc., the desire and effort of that kind would also be absent, and there would be the undesirable consequence of the cessation of all activity and inactivity.

original: svaprakāśatvaṃ jñānāśrayatayā prakāśamānatvaṃ ca na svajñānātirekeṇopapadyata iti / /
analyzed: sva prakāśa tvam jñāna āśraya tayā prakāśamāna tvam ca na sva jñāna atirekeṇa upapadyate iti
translated: Self-luminousness and being manifested as the substratum of knowledge are not possible without the knowledge of itself.

original: chidādiṣu kartṛkarmaṇorbhedadaśarnāttadekatvābhyupagamo viruddha iti yaduktaṃ tannirākaroti kartṛkarmeti //
analyzed: chid ādiṣu kartṛ karmaṇoḥ bheda daśarnāt tad ekatva abhyupagamaḥ viruddhaḥ iti yat uktam tat nirākaroti kartṛ karma iti
translated: It has been argued that the acceptance of the oneness of the agent and object is contradicted by the perception of difference between them in cutting etc. This is refuted by 'The contradiction between agent and object' etc.

analyzed: kartṛ karma virodhaḥ ca nitya anubhava virodhataḥ
translated: The contradiction between agent and object is contradicted by the eternal experience.

analyzed: katham eva padam gacchet virodhaḥ dṛṣṭa bādhanam
translated: How can the contradiction, which is the obstruction of the seen, ever stand?

analyzed: ekasyām kriyāyām kartṛ karma tvayoḥ virodhaḥ kartṛ karma virodhaḥ
translated: The contradiction between agent and object is the contradiction between the agent and object in a single action.
Eternal experience is the experienced witness mentioned above.

analyzed: padam āspadam prakṛtaḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The word 'pada' means 'support', the rest is understood.

analyzed: ayam āśayaḥ  uktam etat liṅga pāde
translated: This is the idea.🔽This has been stated in the chapter on the Linga.

analyzed: yad kartṛ karmaṇoḥ bhedaḥ iti autsargikaḥ yam nyāyaḥ
translated: This is the general rule that the agent and object are different.

analyzed: apavāde satya bhedaḥ pi bhavati iti
translated: And even difference is possible when there is a contradiction.

original: atra ca māmahaṃ jānāmīti sākṣyanubhavavirodhānnāyamasya nyāyasya viṣayaḥ /
analyzed: atra ca mām aham jānāmi iti sākṣī anubhava virodhāt na ayam asya nyāyasya viṣayaḥ
translated: And here, this is not the subject of this reasoning, because of the contradiction with the direct experience I know myself.

analyzed: kintu yatra adṛṣṭa bādhanam pramāṇa virodha abhāvaḥ tatra eva ayam virodhaḥ pravartate  yathā aṅguli agreṇa aṅguli agra sparśane
translated: But this contradiction occurs only where there is no contradiction with valid cognition in the form of an unseen [fact].🔽For example, in the contact of one finger-tip with another finger-tip.

analyzed: yathā vā asi dhārayā asi dhārā chedane iti  astu evam īśvarasya jñeya tvam
translated: Or, in the cutting of a sword-edge with another sword-edge.🔽Let it be so that God is knowable.

analyzed: jīvasya ca svajñāni tvam
translated: And let the individual soul be self-cognizant.

original: tathāpi muktau tajjñānābhāvaḥ kathamaniṣya iti cet /
analyzed: tathā api muktau tad jñāna abhāvaḥ katham aniṣyaḥ iti ced
translated: Even so, how can the absence of that knowledge in liberation be undesirable? If this is asked,

original: ucyate /🔽nātmānaṃ na parāṃścaiva na satyaṃ nāpi cānṛtam /
analyzed: ucyate  na ātmānam na parān ca eva na satyam na api ca anṛtam
translated: it is said:

original: prājñaḥ kiñcana saṃvetti turyaṃ tatsarvadṛk sadā' /
analyzed: prājñaḥ kiñcana saṃvetti turyam tat sarva dṛś sadā
translated: The wise one does not experience anything at all, namely, the self, others, truth, or falsehood. But that fourth [state] always sees everything.

original: iti śrutau svajñānamīśvarajñānaṃ ca nāstītyabhidhāya muktasya tu tadastītyucyate /
analyzed: iti śrutau sva jñānam īśvara jñānam ca nā asti iti abhidhāya muktasya tu tat asti iti ucyate
translated: Having stated in the scripture that there is no self-knowledge or knowledge of God, it is said that the liberated one has that [knowledge].

analyzed: atas tad abhāvaḥ pramāṇa viruddhaḥ iti katham na aniṣyaḥ
translated: Therefore, the absence of that is contradicted by valid cognition. How can it not be undesirable?

original: na kevalamevamaniṣyaprakaraṇādviṣayabhogābhāvasyāniṣṭatvaṃ gamyate kintu viṣayabhogasyāpi śrutisiddhatvāccetyāha sa iti //
analyzed: na kevalam evam aniṣya prakaraṇāt viṣaya bhoga abhāvasya aniṣṭa tvam gamyate kintu viṣaya bhogasya api śruti siddha tvāt ca iti āha saḥ iti
translated: Not only is the undesirability of the absence of enjoyment of objects understood from the section on undesirable consequences, but also because the enjoyment of objects is established by scripture. He says sa (he) etc.

analyzed: sā u śnute sarva kāman ca kāmānnī kāmarūpī atha
translated: He enjoys all desires, desires, and the desire for form.

analyzed: ityādi śrutayaḥ ca uktam artham eva vadanti hi
translated: And the scriptures beginning with this state the very same meaning.

analyzed: atha mukteḥ anantaram iti śruti dvayasya upakrame sambaddhayate
translated: Now, the two scriptures beginning with after liberation are connected.

analyzed: uktam eva artham muktasya viṣaya bhoga sadbhāvam
translated: The very same meaning, the existence of the enjoyment of objects by the liberated one, is stated.

analyzed: atas eva mātrābhiḥ a saṃsargaḥ iti vyākhyānam asat eva iti
translated: For this very reason, the explanation because of non-contact with the limiting adjuncts is indeed false.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

original: yatra hi dvaitamiva bhavatīti ivaśabdena dvaitābhāvaḥ pratipādyate tatkathaṃ dvaitābhāve 'niṣyaprasaṅgābhidhānametadityata āha asvātantryāditi
analyzed: yatra hi dvaitam iva bhavati iti ivaśabdena dvaita abhāvaḥ pratipādyate tat katham dvaita abhāve etat iti atas āha asvātantryāt iti
translated: Where the absence of duality is indicated by the word iva (as if) in where there is duality as it were, how is this statement of undesirable consequences in the absence of duality? To this he says because of non-independence etc.

analyzed: asvātantryāt iva iti uktam na dvaita abhāvataḥ kvacid
translated: It is said because of non-independence, not because of the absence of duality anywhere.

analyzed: dvaitasya asvātantryam abhipretya dvaitam iva iti uktam
translated: Duality is said to be as it were with reference to the non-independence of duality.

analyzed: na tu dvaita abhāvam abhipretya
translated: But not with reference to the absence of duality.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why?

analyzed: kvacid abhidhāna ādau iva śabdasya abhāva vāci tā anukteḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: In some places, like in the statement, the meaning is that the word 'iva' is not said to denote non-existence.

original: asvātantryaṃ cātra svarūpamātramuktam /🔽ivaśabdasyābhāvārthatve bādhakaṃ cāha ātmaiveti /
analyzed: asvātantryam ca atra svarūpa mātram uktam  ivaśabdasya abhāva artha tve bādhakam ca āha ātmā eva iti
translated: And the lack of independence here is said to be mere nature.🔽He states the contradiction in the meaning of 'iva' as non-existence with 'ātmaiva' (the Self alone).

analyzed: ātmā eva abhūt iti hi asmāt aviśeṣa prasaṅgataḥ
translated: For from 'the Self alone became' there would be the undesirable consequence of non-distinction.

original: ivaśabdasyābhāvārthatve dvaitamiva bhavatītyasya dvaitaṃ nāstītyarthaḥ syāt /
analyzed: ivaśabdasya abhāva artha tve dvaitam iva bhavati iti asya dvaitam na asti iti arthaḥ syāt
translated: If 'iva' had the meaning of non-existence, the meaning of 'becomes as if dual' would be 'there is no duality'.

original: yatra tvasya sarvamātmaivābhūdityasya tāvad dvaitābhāvo 'rthaḥ sphuṭa eva /
analyzed: yatra tu asya sarvam ātmā eva abhūt iti asya tāvat dvaita abhāvaḥ rthaḥ sphuṭaḥ eva
translated: As for 'but when all this has become the Self alone', the meaning of non-duality is clear.

analyzed: tatas tasmāt asya viśeṣaḥ na bhavet
translated: Therefore, there would be no distinction from that.

original: tathā ca dvaitābhāve itara itaraṃ paśyet /
analyzed: tathā ca dvaita abhāve itaraḥ itaram paśyet
translated: And in that way, in the absence of duality, one would see another.

original: dvaitābhāve kena kaṃ paśyediti vākyadvayārthaḥ prasajyeta /
analyzed: dvaita abhāve kena kam paśyet iti vākya dvaya arthaḥ prasajyeta
translated: The meaning of the two statements 'by whom would one see another in the absence of duality?' would be implied.

analyzed: tatas ca unmatta vākya tā śruteḥ āpadyate iti
translated: And then the Veda would become a statement of a madman.

analyzed: nanu iva śabdasya asvātantrya vāci tvam kutas iti atas āha asvātantrya iti
translated: But how is it known that the word 'iva' denotes lack of independence? To this he says 'in lack of independence'.

analyzed: asvātantrya upamā bheda bhedeṣu iva udīritaḥ
translated: It is said that in lack of independence, similarity, difference, and non-difference, 'iva' is used.

analyzed: śabda tattvaḥ iti
translated: It is said that this is the truth of words.

analyzed: abheda bheda iti pratīyogi dvaya upalakṣaṇam
translated: The expression non-difference and difference is a reference to the two opposites.

original: ivānta ekasminnukte tatpratiyogī dvitīyo 'pi labhyata ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: iva ante ekasmin ukte tad pratiyogī labhyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that when one is stated, the second, which is its opposite, is also understood.

analyzed: nanu asmākam upamāyām eva ivaśabdaḥ
translated: If it is argued that for us the word iva (like) is only in the simile,

analyzed: dvaita abhāvaḥ tu artha siddhaḥ
translated: and the absence of duality is established by the meaning,

analyzed: layaḥ yatas muktiḥ iyam surāṇām

original: yataḥ kāraṇātsurāṇāṃ laya eveyaṃ muktirna tu manuṣyāṇāmiva prāgeva dehādutkrāntiḥ /
analyzed: yatas kāraṇāt surāṇām layaḥ evā iyam muktiḥ na tu manuṣyāṇām iva prāk eva dehāt utkrāntiḥ
translated: From where, from that cause, this is the dissolution itself of the gods, not the prior departure from the body like that of humans.

analyzed: tasmāt uktam yuktam
translated: Therefore, what is said is proper.

analyzed: sāmānya viśeṣa bhāvāt na sādhya viśiṣya tā doṣaḥ
translated: There is no fault of the conclusion being qualified due to the general and specific nature.

original: sargaścoktānuguṇa eva śrutyādisiddha iti bhāvaḥ /🔽nanu prāṅ muktānāṃ bhogādikaṃ samarthitam /
analyzed: sargaḥ ca ukta anuguṇaḥ eva śruti ādi siddhaḥ iti bhāvaḥ  nanu prāk muktānām bhoga ādikam samarthitam
translated: The creation is said to be in accordance with the scriptures, etc. This is the meaning.

analyzed: idānīm tu ucyate layaḥ eva muktiḥ iti
translated: Now, it is said that liberation is only dissolution.

original: tatkathaṃ pūrvāparavirodho na bhavatītyata āha bhoga iti // /
analyzed: tat katham pūrva apara virodhaḥ na bhavati iti atas āha bhogaḥ iti
translated: How is it that there is no contradiction between the earlier and later statements? To this he says: Enjoyment, etc.

analyzed: bhogaḥ viśeṣeṇa ca
translated: Enjoyment is especially...

analyzed: viśeṣeṇa deva padāt api atiśayena
translated: Specially, even beyond the state of gods.

original: dehahānilakṣaṇā muktirlayānna viśiṣyata ityuktaṃ na tu sarvāpīti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: deha hāni lakṣaṇā muktiḥ layāt na viśiṣyate iti uktam na tu sarvā api iti bhāvaḥ
translated: It is said that liberation characterized by the loss of the body does not differ from dissolution, but not that all liberation is so. This is the meaning.

analyzed: atas eva prāk iyam iti uktam
translated: For this very reason, it was said earlier.

original: bhogaśca muktiriti sūtrakārānuktaṃ kasmādupasaṅkhayeyamityata āha yamiti //
analyzed: bhogaḥ ca muktiḥ iti sūtra kāra an uktam kasmāt upasaṅkhayeyam iti atas āha yam iti
translated: Why should he include enjoyment as liberation, which is not mentioned by the author of the aphorisms? To this he says: He will say...

analyzed: yam vadiṣyati
translated: He will say...

original: yaṃ bhogaṃ caturthapāde sūtrakāro vakṣyati muktitvena saḥ /
analyzed: yam bhogam caturtha pāde sūtrakāraḥ vakṣyati mukti tvena saḥ
translated: That enjoyment which the author of the aphorisms will describe in the fourth chapter as liberation.

analyzed: pramāṇa antaram ca āha uktaḥ ca iti
translated: He states another proof: And it is said...

analyzed: uktaḥ ca bimba pratibimba bhāvaḥ piṅga śrutau ukta laya anusārataḥ
translated: And it is said that there is the relation of original and reflection, in accordance with the stated dissolution, in the Pingala Sruti...

analyzed: bimba pratibimba bhāvaḥ devānām ukta laya anusārataḥ iti
translated: The relation of original and reflection of the gods, in accordance with the stated dissolution.

original: yasminyasyāsmābhirlaya uktaḥ sa bimbaḥ aparaḥ pratibimba ityuktamastītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: yasmin yasya asmābhiḥ layaḥ uktaḥ sa bimbaḥ aparaḥ pratibimbaḥ iti uktam asti iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the object in which the dissolution of that (reflection) has been stated by us is the original object, and the other is said to be the reflection.

original: tataḥ kimityata āha bimba iti //🔽bimbe layo yanniyataśca muktau cidātmanāṃ tadvaśatā ca sarvadā // / / //
analyzed: tatas kim iti atas āha bimbaḥ iti  bimbe layaḥ yat niyataḥ ca muktau cit ātmanām tad vaśa tā ca sarvadā
translated: What then? With this, he says:🔽The dissolution of the reflection in the original object is certain at the time of liberation, and the subordination of the conscious selves to it is always...

analyzed: mokṣa anantaram api sarvadā
translated: Even after liberation, always.

analyzed: etat uttaratra upayogi  prasaṅgāt iha uktam
translated: This is useful later.🔽It is stated here incidentally.

original: yadyasmānmuktau pratibimbasya bimbe layo niyataḥ pramāṇaprasiddhaḥ /
analyzed: yadi asmāt muktau pratibimbasya bimbe layaḥ niyataḥ pramāṇa prasiddhaḥ
translated: Because, at the time of liberation, the dissolution of the reflection in the original object is certain and well-known.

analyzed: tāni ca anyatra tasmāt uktam yuktam iti
translated: And those (consciousnesses) are in another (than the original object). Therefore, what has been said is proper.

original: yaduktaṃ sarveṣāṃ bhūtānāṃ prāṇe layastasya viṣṇāviti tadasat /
analyzed: yat uktam sarveṣām bhūtānām prāṇe layaḥ tasya viṣṇau iti tat asat
translated: What has been said - that all beings dissolve in the vital air, and that dissolves in Vishnu - is not correct.

analyzed: prāṇaḥ tejasi tejanaḥ parasyām devatāyām
translated: The vital air dissolves in fire, and fire in the supreme deity.

original: iti śrutivirodhāt /🔽bimbe pratibimbasya laya iti cāsat /
analyzed: iti śruti virodhāt  bimbe pratibimbasya layaḥ iti ca asat
translated: Because this is contradicted by the scriptures.🔽And it is not correct that the reflection dissolves in the original object.

original: nahi prāṇastejābhūtasya pratibimba ityata āha tejo 'bhidhāmiti //
analyzed: nahi prāṇaḥ tejābhūtasya pratibimbaḥ iti atas āha tejaḥ
translated: Because the vital air is not a reflection of what is made of fire. With this in mind, he says:

original: tejo 'bhidhāṃ tu śriyamāpya viṣṇumagre tataḥ putratayaiva vāyuḥ /
analyzed: tejaḥ bhidhām tu śriyam āpya viṣṇum agre tatas putra tayā eva vāyuḥ
translated: But having attained Vishnu, who is designated as fire, Vayu (the vital air) first goes to him as his son.

original: āptaḥ prasūtaḥ punareva viṣṇuṃ praviśya muktaḥ praḷaye 'tra tiṣṭhati // / /f //
analyzed: āptaḥ prasūtaḥ punar eva viṣṇum praviśya muktaḥ praḷaye tra tiṣṭhati
translated: Having attained, having been born, he again enters Vishnu, and being liberated, he remains here in Vishnu at the time of dissolution.

original: vāyuḥ pralaye tejo 'bhidhāṃ śriyamāpya tatra līno bhūtvā viṣṇumāptaḥ /
analyzed: vāyuḥ pralaye tejaḥ bhidhām śriyam āpya tatra līnaḥ bhūtvā viṣṇum āptaḥ
translated: The wind, having attained the glory designated as fire, and having become absorbed there, attains Vishnu.

analyzed: sṛṣṭi kāle jāte gre sarvebhyaḥ pūrvam
translated: When the time of creation arrives, he is born first, before all.

analyzed: tatas viṣṇoḥ
translated: Then from Vishnu.

analyzed: putra tayā hiraṇya garbha tvena prasūtaḥ
translated: He is born as the son, as Hiranyagarbha.

original: punareva pralaye muktau viṣṇuṃ praviśya atra viṣṇau tiṣṭhati /
analyzed: punar eva pralaye muktau viṣṇum praviśya atra viṣṇau tiṣṭhati
translated: Again, at the time of dissolution, having entered Vishnu, he remains here in Vishnu.

analyzed: idam uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

original: tejaḥśabdasya lakṣmīvācitvānnoktavirodhaḥ /🔽evaṃ tarhivilīno hi prakṛtau saṃsārameti' /
analyzed: tejaḥ śabdasya lakṣmī vāci tvāt na ukta virodhaḥ  evam tarhi vilīnaḥ hi prakṛtau saṃsāram eti
translated: Since the word tejas denotes Lakshmi, there is no contradiction with what was said.

analyzed: iti śruteḥ vāyoḥ saṃsāra prasaṅgaḥ iti ced na
translated: If that is so, then it may be argued that the wind would be subject to worldly existence, since it is said in the Upanishad: For he who is absorbed in Prakriti, enters into worldly existence.

analyzed: iṣṭa tvāt
translated: This is not so, because it is accepted.

analyzed: hiraṇyagarbha tvena punajarnana aṅgīkārāt
translated: Because the rebirth as Hiranyagarbha is accepted.

analyzed: evam api brahma vidaḥ mukti abhāva prasaṅgaḥ iti ced na
translated: Even so, it may be argued that there would be no liberation for one who knows Brahman. This is not so.
Because liberation after the state of Hiranyagarbha is accepted.

analyzed: idam ca prāṇa śabdasya vāyu vāci tva pakṣam ādāya uktam
translated: And this is said taking the side that the word prana denotes the wind.

analyzed: hiraṇyagarbha vācitva pakṣe tu bhāṣya uktam draṣṭavyam
translated: But on the side that it denotes Hiranyagarbha, it should be seen as stated in the commentary.

analyzed: muktānām svasta uttamadevatāḥ praviśya avasthānam iti uktam
translated: It has been said that the liberated souls enter and abide in the supreme deity.

analyzed: na etāvat eva
translated: But this is not all.

analyzed: kintu bhagavat praveśaḥ pi asti
translated: There is also entry into the Lord.

original: uktaśca bhogo nānandasya janakaḥ kintu vyañjaka eva /
analyzed: uktaḥ ca bhogaḥ nā ānandasya janakaḥ kintu vyañjakaḥ eva
translated: And it has been said that enjoyment is not the cause of bliss, but only its revealer.

original: ānandastu svarūpabhūta ityāha sarve 'pīti //🔽sarve 'pi te muktagaṇā amandasāndraṃ nijānandamaśeṣato 'pi /
analyzed: ānandaḥ tu svarūpa bhūtaḥ iti āha sarve pi iti  sarve pi te mukta gaṇāḥ amanda sāndram nija ānandam aśeṣatas
translated: But bliss is of the nature of the Self. Thus it is said:🔽All those groups of liberated souls, to the fullest extent, enjoy their own intense bliss.

original: bhuñjanta evāsata īśadehe laye 'tha sarge bahireva yānti // / / //
analyzed: bhuñjantaḥ eva asataḥ īśa dehe laye sarge bahis eva yānti
translated: They remain in the body of the Lord in dissolution, and in creation they go out.

original: sarve 'pītyukte devānāṃ prakṛtatvātta eveti pratītiṃ vārayitumaśeṣato 'pītyuktam /
analyzed: sarve pi iti ukte devānām prakṛta tvāt te eva iti pratītim vārayitum aśeṣatas pi iti uktam
translated: When it is said all, it is said to the fullest extent to avoid the notion that only the gods are meant, since they are the subject.

analyzed: bhuñjantaḥ anubhavantaḥ
translated: Enjoying means experiencing.

analyzed: śiṣṭāḥ havyavāham iti asya apavāda antaram āha prayāti iti
translated: The remainder is Havya-vaha. He states another exception: He goes.

original: prayāti dharmaṃ nirṛtistu śakraṃ marudgaṇāḥ pārṣadāstathaiva /
analyzed: prayāti dharmam nirṛtiḥ tu śakram marut gaṇāḥ pārṣadāḥ tathā eva
translated: Nirrti goes to Dharma, the Marut-groups and the attendants to Shakra,

analyzed: sarve niruddham pṛtanā adhipa ādyāḥ
translated: all to Aniruddha, beginning with the commanders of the army.

analyzed: nirṛtiḥ tu dharmam prayāti
translated: But Nirrti goes to Dharma.

analyzed: marut gaṇāḥ śakram prayānti
translated: The Marut-groups go to Shakra.

analyzed: tathāśabdaḥ samuccaye
translated: The word tatha (thus) is for inclusion.

original: pṛtanādhipādyā viṣvaksenādyāḥ sarve bhagavataḥ pārṣadā aniruddhaṃ prayānti /
analyzed: pṛtanādhipa ādyāḥ viṣvaksena ādyāḥ sarve bhagavataḥ pārṣadāḥ aniruddham prayānti
translated: The commanders of the army, headed by Visvaksena, all the personal attendants of the Lord, go to Aniruddha.

analyzed: deha laya artham iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is that it is for the sake of the dissolution of the body.

original: aniruddhasya tu kāme laya ukta evetyevārthaḥ /
analyzed: aniruddhasya tu kāme layaḥ uktaḥ eva iti eva arthaḥ
translated: But the dissolution of Aniruddha in Kama has already been stated. This is the meaning.

analyzed: atra pramāṇam āha tura iti
translated: Here, he states the proof with Tura.

analyzed: turaśrutiḥ hi ittham
translated: For thus is the Vedic text of Tura.

analyzed: atas eva etat tatra eva na uktam parama śrutau anukta tvāt
translated: For this very reason, this is not stated there, because it is not mentioned in the supreme Vedic text.

analyzed: pāda artham upasaṃharati iyam iti
translated: He concludes the meaning of the chapter with This.

analyzed: iyam vimuktiḥ
translated: This is liberation.

analyzed: deva ādīnām deha laya rūpā vimuktiḥ uktā iti
translated: It is said that the liberation of the gods and others is in the form of the dissolution of the body.

analyzed: iti śrīmat pūrṇapramati bhagavat pāda su kṛteḥ anuvyākhyānasya praguṇa jayatīrtha ākhya yatinā
translated: Thus, in the commentary written by the ascetic named Praguṇajayatīrtha, who is very virtuous and is the disciple of the revered Pūrṇapramati Bhagavatpāda,

analyzed: kṛtāyām ṭīkāyām viṣama pada vākya artha vivṛtau caturthe dhyāye tra utkramaṇa caraṇaḥ paryavasitaḥ
translated: on the fourth chapter of the commentary called Viṣamapaṭhīya, which explains the meaning of the verses, the section on the process of departure has been completed.

analyzed: adhyaya pada
translated: Chapter. Verse.

original: mārgo gamyaṃ cāsminpāda ucyata iti bhāṣyam /
analyzed: mārgaḥ gamyam ca asmin pāde ucyate iti bhāṣyam
translated: The commentary says that in this section, the path and the goal are discussed.

analyzed: tat prāk prasaṅgāt vivṛtam api iha avara prāptau viśeṣataḥ vivṛṇoti utkrāntā iti
translated: Although this has been explained earlier incidentally, it is explained again specifically in the context of attaining the higher state, with Utkramāṇam (departure).

analyzed: utkrānta mārgaḥ ca vimukta gamyam pāda uditam
translated: And the path of departure is to be reached by those liberated, and is taught in this section.

analyzed: ye śarīrāt utkrāntāḥ mānuṣāḥ teṣām mārgaḥ bhagavat loka gamana arthaḥ
translated: For those who have departed from the body, the path is for the purpose of going to the world of the Blessed One.

analyzed: gamyam api teṣām eva iti pratīti nirāsāya uktam vimukta iti
translated: In order to remove the understanding that it is also to be reached by them, it is said by those liberated.

original: ye karmaṇo dehācca vimuktāsteṣāṃ sarveṣāmapi gamyam /
analyzed: ye karmaṇaḥ dehāt ca vimuktāḥ teṣām sarveṣām api gamyam
translated: It is to be reached by all those who are liberated from action and the body.

analyzed: idam ubhayam etat pāda uditam
translated: Both of these are taught in this section.

analyzed: atra adhikaraṇeṣu pūrvapakṣa yuktiḥ siddhānta yuktīḥ ca āha su krama iti
translated: In these topics, he states the arguments for the prima facie view and the arguments for the conclusion, beginning with sukrameti.

original: sukramavikramau ca // / / // /🔽sāntānikaṃ prāptirabhīṣyatā ca saukayarmityanyamatasya tarkāḥ // / / //🔽viśeṣasamprāptirurutvamāptiḥ kramānurāgaḥ kathitānuvṛttiḥ /
analyzed: sukrama vikramau ca  sāntānikam prāptiḥ abhīṣya tā ca saukayarmiti anya matasya tarkāḥ  viśeṣa samprāptiḥ uru tvam āptiḥ krama anurāgaḥ kathita anuvṛttiḥ
translated: And Sukra and Vikrama,🔽The arguments of others are: the attainment of the continuum, the desire for attainment, and the ease of attainment.🔽Attainment of distinction, attainment of greatness, conformity to order, and conformity to what is stated,

analyzed: siddhānta nirṇīti karāḥ  anya matasya iti jātau ekavacanam
translated: Are stated as the arguments that determine the conclusion.🔽Of others is the singular form for the neuter.

analyzed: siddhānta nirṇīti karāḥ tarkāḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is: The arguments that determine the conclusion.

original: oṃ apratīkālambanānnayatīti bādarāyaṇa ubhayathā ca doṣāttatkratuśca oṃ //
analyzed: om a pratīka ālambanāt nayati iti bādarāyaṇaḥ ubhayathā ca doṣāt tad kratuḥ ca om
translated: Om. Badarayana says it leads to the unseen object. And because of the fault in both ways, and because of the conviction in that. Om.

analyzed: vimukta gamyam pratipādayitum idam sūtram
translated: This sutra is for the purpose of teaching what is to be reached by the liberated.

original: tadbhāṣye na vispaṣṭamityataḥ spaṣṭīkariṣyanpratīkaśabdārthaṃ tāvadāha pratīkamiti // /
analyzed: tad bhāṣye na vispaṣṭam iti atas spaṣṭīkariṣyan pratīka śabda artham tāvat āha pratīkam iti
translated: Since that commentary is not clear, he who wishes to clarify it, first explains the meaning of the word 'pratika' (symbol).

original: apratīkālambanān nayatīti bādarāyaṇa ubhayathā ca doṣāt tatkratuś ca / / / /
analyzed: a pratīka ālambanāt nayati iti bādarāyaṇaḥ ubhayathā ca doṣāt tad kratuḥ ca
translated: Badarayana says that one is led to the non-symbol-based (worship) because of the fault in both ways, and because of the resolve on that (symbol).

analyzed: pratīkam deha ādikam
translated: The symbol is the body etc.

analyzed: ādi padena manaḥ prabhṛtīnām bhagavat pratimānām grahaṇam
translated: By the word 'etc.' the inclusion of the mind and so on, which are images of the Lord, is meant.

original: yadyapi sūtre 'pratīkālambanānāṃ gamyamuktaṃ pratīkālambanānāṃ tu pariśeṣasiddham /
analyzed: yadi api sūtre pratīka ālambanānām gamyam uktam pratīka ālambanānām tu pariśeṣa siddham
translated: Although in the sutra it is said that the object of those who have non-symbol-based (worship) is stated, but that of those who have symbol-based (worship) is established by elimination.

analyzed: tathā api aspaṣṭa spaṣṭīkaraṇa artham pravṛtta tvāt abhāvasya bhāva pūrvaka tvāt ca pariśeṣa siddham eva artham ādau āha tad gatam iti
translated: Nevertheless, because it is engaged for the purpose of clarifying what is unclear, and because non-existence is preceded by existence, he takes the meaning established by elimination and says that which pertains to that.

analyzed: tad gatam eva ye narāḥ
translated: Those men who worship only that which pertains to that (symbol),

analyzed: upāsate te puratas samāpnuyuḥ brahmāṇam asmāt matim āpya viṣṇum
translated: they will attain Brahman and Vishnu before (us).

analyzed: prāpsyanti
translated: They will attain...

analyzed: pratīka gatam eva viṣṇum
translated: Vishnu who is in the symbol.

analyzed: te pratīka ālambanāḥ
translated: They are those who have symbol-based (worship).

analyzed: puratas prāk pralaya kālāt
translated: Before, before the time of dissolution.

analyzed: asmāt brahmaṇaḥ
translated: From this Brahman.

analyzed: matim bhagavat jñāna viśeṣam
translated: The understanding, the special knowledge of the Lord.

analyzed: prāpsyanti pralaye
translated: They will attain at the time of dissolution.

original: idānīṃ sūtritāmapratīkālambanānāṃ gatiṃ prapañcayati ata iti //
analyzed: idānīm sūtritām apratīka ālambanānām gatim prapañcayati atas iti
translated: Now he elaborates on the course of those who do not attain liberation immediately, as stated in the sutra, beginning with ataḥ (therefore).

original: ato 'nye 'pi tamāpya tasmāddhariṃ gatā muktibhājaḥ parānte // / / //
analyzed: atas nye pi tam āpya tasmāt harim gatāḥ mukti bhājaḥ parānte
translated: Therefore, others who worship the Void also go to that Hari in the end, being entitled to liberation.

analyzed: pratīka ālambanebhyaḥ nye vyopta upāsakāḥ a pratīka ālambanāḥ
translated: Those who worship the Void are different from those who attain liberation immediately.

analyzed: prathamatas tam viṣṇum āpya api parānta kāle
translated: Having first attained that Vishnu, in the end.

analyzed: tasmāt viṣṇoḥ tam brahmāṇam āpya harim gatāḥ bhavanti iti
translated: Having attained that Brahman from Vishnu, they go to Hari.

original: iti śrīmatpūṇarpramatibhagavatpādasukṛteranuvyākhyānasya praguṇajayatīrthākhyayatinā kṛtāyāṃ ṭīkāyāṃ viṣamapādavākyārthavivṛtau caturthādhyāye🔽smingamanacaraṇaḥ paryavasitaḥ //
analyzed: iti śrīmat pūṇa ṛpra mati bhagavat pāda sukṛteḥ anuvyākhyānasya praguṇa jayatīrtha ākhya yatinā kṛtāyām ṭīkāyām viṣama pāda vākya artha vivṛtau caturtha adhyāye  smin gamana caraṇaḥ paryavasitaḥ
translated: Thus ends the chapter on going in the commentary on the sub-commentary of the illustrious Punar-pramatir Bhagavatpada Sukriti, composed by the ascetic named Praguṇajayati, explaining the meaning of the difficult passages in the fourth chapter.

original: iti śrīmannyāyasudhāyāṃ caturthādhyāyasya tṛtīyaḥ pādaḥ // 🔽Adhyaya / Pada /
analyzed: iti śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām caturtha adhyāyasya tṛtīyaḥ pādaḥ  adhyaya pada
translated: Thus ends the fourth quarter in the Nyāyasudhā.

analyzed: atha śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām caturtha adhyāyasya caturthaḥ pādaḥ
translated: Now begins the fourth quarter of the fourth chapter of the illustrious Nyāyasudhā.

analyzed: pāda pratipādyam tad saṅgatiḥ ca prasiddhā evā iti atas pūrva uttara pakṣa yuktiḥ evā āha atikrama iti
translated: The subject matter of the quarter and its connection are well known. Therefore, he states the arguments for the prima facie view and the final view, beginning with atikrama (transgression).

analyzed: atikrama uktiḥ kṛtiḥ artha lābhaḥ parā gatiḥ pāra gatiḥ tat okaḥ
translated: Transgression, statement, accomplishment, gain of wealth, supreme attainment, attainment of the other shore, and its abode,
